editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE TRYAL OF Sr Tho. Gascoyne Bar. FOR HIGH-TREASON, In Conspiring The Death of the KING, THE Subversion of the GOVERNMENT, AND Alteration of RELIGION, On Wednesday the 11th of February 1679.
At the Bar of the KINGS BENCH, BEFORE The Right Honourable Sir William Scroggs Lord Chief Justice, And the rest of the Judges of that Court.
LONDON: Printed for Tho. Basset, and Sam. Heyrick; at the George in Fleet-street, and at Greys-Inne-gate in Holborn. 1680.

div.head: THE TRYAL OF Sir Tho. Gascoyne Bar.
div.p: On Saturday the 24th of Jan. 1679, Sir Tho. Gascoyne was brought to the Bar of the Court of Kings-bench, to be Arraigned for HighTreason; which was done accordingly in this manner.

sp.speaker: Clerk of Crown.
sp.p: SIr Thomas Gascoyne, hold up thy hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gasc.
sp.p: I cannot hear.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: He saies he cannot hear.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then somebody must repeat it that stands by him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Do you hear what I say to you?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gasc.
sp.p: No, I cannot hear, I am very deaf.

div.p: Then the Clerk of the Crown went down close to the Bar, and went on thus:

sp.speaker: Clerk of Crown.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Gascoyne, hold up thy hand.

Thou standest indicted by the name of Sir Thomas Gascoyne, late of the Parish of Elmett in the West-riding in the County of York, Bar. for that thou, as a false Traytor against our most Illustrious and excellent Prince King Charles the second, thy natural Lord, not having the fear of God in thy heart, nor weighing the duty of thy Allegiance, but by the instigation of the Devil moved and seduced, the cordial love, and true, due, and natural obedience which true and faithful Subjects of our said Lord the King should bear to him, and of right are bound to bear, wholly withdrawing, devising,
and with all thy power intending to disturb the Peace and common Tranquillity of this Realm, and to bring and put our said Lord the King to death and final destruction; and the true Worship of God in this Kingdom, by Law established and used, to alter unto the Superstition of the Church of Rome, and to move and stir up War against our said Lord the King in this Realm, and to subvert the Government of this Kingdom; The thirtieth day of May, in the one and thirtieth year of our said Lord the King's Reign, at the Parish of Barwick in Elmett in the said County of York, in the West-Riding of the same County, with divers other false Traytors unknown, didst trayterously compass, imagine, and intend the death and final destruction of our said Lord the King; and to change and alter, and wholly to subvert the ancient Government of this Realm; and to depose, and wholly to deprive the King of the Crown and Government of this Kingdom; and to root out the true Protestant Religion. And to fulfil and accomplish the same most wicked Treasons and trayterous Imaginations and Purposes, the said Gascoyne, and other false Traytors unknown, on the said thirtieth day of May, in the one and thirtieth year aforesaid, with Force and Arms, &c. at the Parish of Barwick aforesaid, advisedly, divelishly, maliciously, and trayterously, did assemble, unite, and gather together themselves, and then and there did devilishly, advisedly, maliciously, craftily, and trayterously consult and agree to bring our said Lord the King to death and final destruction, and to depose and deprive him of his Crown and Government, and to introduce and establish the Religion of the Roman Church in this Realm. And the sooner to fulfil and accomplish the same most wicked Treasons and trayterous Imaginations and purposes, thou the said Gascoyne, and other unknown Traytors, then and there, advisedly, maliciously, and trayterously, did further consult and agree to contribute, pay, and expend divers large sums of money to divers of the King's Subjects and other persons unknown, to procure those persons unknown trayterously to kill our said Lord the King, and to introduce the Roman Religion into this Realm. And that thou the said Gascoyne afterwards (to wit) on the said thirtieth day of May, in the one and thirtieth year aforesaid, at the Parish aforesaid, didst falsely, advisedly, craftily, maliciously, and trayterously, sollicit one Robert Bolron to kill our said Lord the King; and then and there, with an intent sooner trayterously to encourage the said Bolron to undertake the killing and murthering of our said Lord the King, offeredst therefore to give and pay the said Bolron a thousand pounds of lawful money of England: against the duty of thy Allegiance, against the Peace of our said Lord the King, his Crown and Dignity, and against the form of the Statute in such Case made and provided. How sayest thou, Sir Thomas Gascoyne, art thou guilty of this High-Treason whereof thou standest indicted, and hast been now arraigned, or not guilty?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoigne.
sp.p: Gloria Patri, Filio & Spiritui Sancto, I am no guiltie.

sp.speaker: Clerk of Crown.
sp.p: Not guiltie, you must say.

sp.speaker: Sir T. Gasc.
sp.p: Not guiltie; nor any of my Familie were ever guiltie of any such thing. I hope I shall be tryed fairly.

sp.speaker: Clerk of Crown.
sp.p: How will you be tryed?

sp.speaker: Sir T. Gasc.
sp.p: By God and my Countrie.

sp.speaker: Clerk of Crown.
sp.p: God send thee a good deliverance.

sp.speaker: Sir T. Gasc.
sp.p: I desire, that in order to my Trial, I may have a Jurie of Gentlemen, of Persons of my own Qualitie, and of my own Countrie, that may be able to know something how I have lived hitherto; for I am above Fourscore and five years old.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Tell him he shall have a good Jurie of Gentlemen of his own Countrie.

sp.speaker: Sir T. Gasc.
sp.p: And besides, my Lord, I desire to know when I shall be tried.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Some time about the latter end of the Term, as soon as I can get a Jurie up.

sp.speaker: Sir T. Gasc.
sp.p: I do not know whether I can produce all my Witnesses at that time, if there be not a longer time allowed me; for I have a great many Witnesses to fetch up. These Witnesses must be all here, or I can't make my Defence; and I know not how they shall be got hither in so little time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Tell him he may have what Witnesses he pleases, and the aid of this Court to fetch them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Dolben.
sp.p: Name them who they are.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: My Lord, some of his Witnesses are at Paris.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Dolben.
sp.p: Why, he will not be tried yet this fortnight.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: They will not have time to come over between this and that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Dolben.
sp.p: Mistriss, he had reason to believe that he should be tried some time this Term; for so the Council ordered it: and therefore he should have got his Witnesses ready.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: My Lord, he did not know where they were till a week ago.

sp.speaker: Mr. J •… stice Dolben.
sp.p: Look you, Mr. Attorney, here is a Ladie that is, I suppose, fome Relation to this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: He is my Grandfather, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Dolben.
sp.p: She saies a fortnights time will be too little to get his Witnesses together for his Defence, because some of the Witnesses are beyond Sea at Paris, she saies.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I am willing he should have as long time as the Term will allow of: But sure that is long enough to get any Witnesses from Paris.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What say you to Sir Miles Stapleton? I see he is joyned in the Indictment.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, he is not come up yet.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Will you trie the one without the other?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, if we cannot have both. He is in the hands of the Messenger at York. We have writ down to know the state of his health to some of the Justices of the Peace, and the Messenger returns word, he is sick and can't come. I have sent down an Habeas Corpus to the Messenger to bring him up; let him return a Languidus at his peril: that's all I can do.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Well, what day do you appoint for Sir Thomas his Trial?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Tuesday come fortnight▪ I think will be a good day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Dolben.
sp.p: By that time, Mistris, you may get your Witnesses; you must send a Messenger on purpose.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: But if the wind should be contrarie, my Lord, and they cannot be brought over?

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Dolben.
sp.p: 'Tis not an usual thing to have the winds long contrarie between Dover and Cali •… e.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: But if it do fall out that he wants a material Witness at his Trial, I hope his life will be considered.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Dolben.
sp.p: He should have had them readie; he had warning before.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: We cou'd do it no sooner, because we knew not where they were.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Dolben.
sp.p: He saith, he hath a great many Witnesses; are they all at Paris?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: There are a great many in Town we know alreadie.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: If we had known when exactly, we might have been more readie perhaps.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: But we could give no notice sooner; it is early in the Term now. But there is time enough to get any Witnesses.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Aye, you may send to Paris a great many times between this and that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: What if the Letter miscarry, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Dolben.
sp.p: Why, you must send a special Messenger.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, if you please, let it be Wednesday fortnight, the last day but one of the Term; because I would give him as much time to provide himself as I can.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Pemberton.
sp.p: Well, Mistriss, you must send a special Messenger; we must not consult your conveniencie; do it as well as you can, you have time enough.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Dolben.
sp.p: Your Grandfather is a man of an Estate, he may very well in this Case be at the charge of a special Messenger.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: But what if the winds be contrarie, must my Grandfather's life be lost?

sp.speaker: L. Chief Justice.
sp.p: We must give you that favour we can by Law, and you must be content. Tell us at the Trial what you have done.

div.p: Then the Lieutenant of the Tower was ordered to take the Prisoner back, and by rule to bring him to the Bar on Wednesday the 11th of February. On which day the Prisoner being brought up, the Tryal proceeded thus:

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, here is an extraordinarie matter: Sir Thomas Gascoigne had a Rule for some friend to assist him, by reason of the defect of his hearing; and now there are three of them that are got among the Jurie.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, no, they must come in of the inside of the Bar.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray let him tell which he will make choice of; for he is by the Rule to have but one.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Pem •… on.
sp.p: Tell him there can but one stay.

sp.speaker: Counsel.
sp.p: He saies one of them came out of the Countrie, and knows the persons that are the Witnesses, which he does not himself.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Justice.
sp.p: Well, let the other come in, let him have them both.

sp.speaker: Counsel.
sp.p: He saies, the principal man he depended upon, is clapt up.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, we can't help that.

div.p: Then way was made for the Jury to come up to the Stand, and Proclamation for Information was made in usual manner.

sp.speaker: Clerk of Court.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Gascoign, hold up thy hand.

sp.speaker: Sir T. Gasc.
sp.p: I cannot hear what is said.

sp.speaker: Clerk of Crown.
sp.p: Those good men which were lately called, and have appeared, are to pass, &c.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Tell him the effect of it. If he will make any Challenges to the Jurie, he must speak before they are sworn.

sp.speaker: Hobart.
sp.p: If you will challenge any of the Jury, you must speak to them before they are sworn.

sp.speaker: Sir T. Gasc.
sp.p: I cannot hear who is called.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Tell him who is called.

sp.speaker: Clerk of Crown.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Hodson.

sp.speaker: Hobart.
sp.p: This is Sir Thomas Hodson, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T. Gasc.
sp.p: What must I say? Aye, or No?

sp.speaker: Hobart.
sp.p: Do you except against him?

sp.speaker: Sir T. Gasc.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Hobart.
sp.p: Do you challenge him, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir T. Gasc.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, here is Sir John Cutler in the Pannel, one that lives in Town, and is the Fore-man of the Jurie; I desire the Court to take notice of his not appearing in particular.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: I perceive they skip a great many; pray call them as they are in the Pannel, and record their Non-appearance in Court.

div.p: Which was done accordingly; but their Names that did not appear, for brevitie sake, are omitted.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We challenge him for the King. I perceive the best Gentlemen stay at home.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis so small a business.

sp.speaker: Clerk of the Crown.
sp.p: Cryer, count these.

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: Twelve, good men and true, stand together and hear your Evidence.

sp.speaker: Clerk of the Crown.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Gascoigne, hold up thy hand. Gentlemen, you of the Jurie that are sworn, look upon the Prisoner, and hearken to his Charge. You shall understand, that he stands indicted by the name of Sir Thomas Gascoigne late of the Parish of Elmet, &c. Prout in the Indictment mutatis mutandis. Upon this Indictment he hath been arraigned, and thereunto pleaded Not guiltie; and for his Trial hath put himself upon his Countrie; which Countrie you are, &c▪

div.p: Then Proclamation for Evidence was made, and Dormer Esq of Counsel for the King in this Cause, opened the Indictment, thus:

sp.speaker: Mr. Dormer.
sp.p: May it please your Lordship, and you, Gentlemen of the Jurie, Sir Thomas Gascoigne Baronet, the Prisoner at the Bar, stands indicted for high Treason, in conspiring the Murder of his Majestie, the Subverting of the Government, and the introducing the Romish Religion. And for the effecting these purposes, the Indictment sets forth, That the said Sir Thomas Gaseoigne, Sir Miles Stapleton, and other false Traytors, the 30th of May last, at the Parish of Elmet in the West-riding of the Countie of York, did assemble together, and there resolved to put their Treasons in execution. And the better to accomplish their said Treasons and traiterous Imaginations, they did agree to contribute several large sums of money to several of his Majesties Subjects unknown, to introduce Poperie, to kill the King, and subvert the Government: And that Sir Thomas Gascoigne did sollicit Robert Bolrond to kill the King, and for that service he was to pay him 1000l. To this he hath pleaded Not guiltie: if the Kings Evidence prove the Charge of the Indictment, your dutie is to finde him guiltie.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p:
May it please your Lordship, and you, Gentlemen of the Jurie, you have heard the Indictment, and it hath been opened to you. There can be no greater Crime charged upon any, than that this Gentleman is accused of. The designe hath been to kill and murder the King, to change the Religion and the Government; and to effect this, they make Assemblies, they offer
Money: and this, my Lord, we shall prove. 'Tis no new Crime, divers have suffered for the like alreadie; and we shall not need to make any aggravations, for indeed it cannot be aggravated more than the plain matter it self is. We shall call our Witnesses, and prove it directly upon him, even by two Witnesses; and we shall prove, that he held intelligence with one Preswicke a Priest; Letters between him and that person are found in his custodie, and we shall produce one of them wherein it does appear, that there was Intelligence between them, and Consultations had about the Oath of Allegiance; and that Praud did write to him, that it was a damnable Oath condemned by the Sorbonnists: And upon that point hangs the changing of Religion; for the Oath of Allegiance is the great Touchstone to discover mens sinceritie by, and the great Bond to tie them to the Government, and to the Protestant Religion. And we shall •… ikewise prove another Passage in a Letter indorsed with the Prisoner's own hand, wherein there is an expression to this purpose: That if England be converted, (the Priest writes this to him) then how a sum of Ninety pound was to be disposed: which was, as you shall hear, and we shall prove, in a Nunnery. If England be converted, that clearly shews what was their intention, not onely to destroy the King, but the Religion and the Nation; and so they were conspiring not onely against his Majestie, but against God. That an old Gentleman that hath lived so long under the peace of this Nation, and been so protected by the Government, which hath been so indulgent to men of his perswafion, should be guiltie of such a designe, is a lamentable thing to think of; That he should so offend the Law, which hath been so milde in its execution against such men. We shall prove the proffer of the 1000 l. and so leave it with you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p:
My Lord, these two Papers we shall use in confirmation of that Evidence will be given by two Witnesses, who I think will concur in the same thing; that is, the conspiracie for killing the King, and for the carrying on of the Plot. The Papers the Witnesses will expound to you; the one is a Letter, as Mr. Serjeant hath opened it to you, to Sir Thomas Gascoigne from a Priest, wherein he does discourse about 90 l. a year at Maunston, which Sir Thomas had purchased to settle upon a Nunnery cal •… ed Dolebank in York-shire; and therein it is said, You will be well advised to put in a Proviso into the former Writing (he meant for the Settlement) That if England be converted, the 90 l. a year sha •… be bestowed at Heworth or some other place in Yorkshire. Your L •… rdship will hear by the Witnesses, that there were several 〈◊〉 designed for these Nuns to inhabit, as Dolebank and other places; and this Letter will concur with their Evidence, and they •… ill pro •… , that this very place that they speak of, was 〈◊〉 for this 〈◊〉 ; and so it appears by the Papers taken in Sir Thoma •…
〈◊〉
custodie. My Lord, there is another Letter which was 〈◊〉 , and which I believe may have a great influence in the Cause, 〈◊◊〉 sure it may
be likely to produce very bad effects, which is that Letter from the Priest, wherein he decries the Oath of Allegiance as a damnable thing condemned by the Doctrines at Sorbonne, and other Priests from Rome. And this had its effect a little time before; for it was ab •… ut the time that a matter of thirty or forty were convicted of a Praemunire in that Countie, for not taking the Oath of Allegiance, which they used to do before. And there will be some other concurring Evidence in this Cause, and that is by some Papers taken in Sir Thomas Gascoigne's own hand; they are Almanacks, in which many of his own Memorials are, several sums of money mentioned to be paid, and returned to Priests at London: the Witnesses will tell you it was returned for the designe of the Plot. There happens to be 900 l. returned to Mr. Corker, who is now in Newgate; and some other sums to Harcourt, who is executed; and some money is paid to him, though I think not much, about 25 l. and several sums are mentioned, and great sums returned to London by Sir Thomas Gascoigne, in five or six years time, 5 or 6000 l. to what purpose I can't tell; they will give you an account: I think he did live always in York-shire himself, never used to come to Town; and what occasion he might have of returning money, I don't know. We will call the two Witnesses viva voce, and then use the other Evidence as we shall have occasion to confirm them. Call Mr. Bolrond and Mr. Mowbray.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Bolrond, tell my Lord and the Jurie what you know of Sir Thomas Gascoigne.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: My Lord, and you, Gentlemen of the Jurie; I came to live with Sir Thomas Gascoigne in the year 1674, as Steward of his Cole-works; and in the year 1675, a little before Easter, being in the next Room to Sir Thomas Gascoigne, I did hear Charles Ingleby and Sir Thomas in discourse together, and Sir Thomas did say, he was very fearful his Estate would be liable to be forfeited to the King—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: In 75 was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What time in 75?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: A little before Easter.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you in the Room?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I was in the next Room, and the door was not shut; and Sir Thomas did say—

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Tell the discourse, what it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: He said he was resolved to make a collusive conveyance of his Estate, for fear it should be forfeited to the King. And Charles Ingleby said, it was best so to do: and then he told Sir Thomas he wou'd have the Defeazance made ready, which he would draw with his own hands; but he bid him be sure to bring none but Protestant Witnesses along with him to testifie. And in the year 1675 I did go along with Sir Thomas Gascoigne to Sir William Ingleby's of Ripley, and there I did see him receive colourably 1000 l.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How do you know it was colourably?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I did hear Sir Thomas tell Charles Ingleby so.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: The 7th or 8th of April; the Deed bears the 8th of April 1675.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was Charles Ingleby there at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes, when the Deed was sealed; and he read it in the presence of the Witnesses to be dated at that time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Dolben.
sp.p: What, that thousand pound was the consideration of the Deed?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes, it was. Sir Thomas Gascoigne did part thereby with all his Estate for seven years, he allowing him 100 l. a year for his maintenance, besides the 1000 l. at first paid. And this was done with that intent, for fear he should be discovered in the Plot for killing the King—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How do you know that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I did hear Sir Thomas Gascoigne and Sir Miles Stapleton discourse of it, and he said it was for that end.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was that discourse?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: In Sir Tho. Gascoigne's Bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Jones.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: It was in or about the discovery of the Plot.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you say you saw the Deed sealed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes, I was a Witness to it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And you saw the money paid?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I and one Matthias Higgringill did help to count it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Jones.
sp.p: Were you a Protestant at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I was at the time of the sealing the Deed; but I did hear the discourse between Sir Miles Stapleton and Sir Thomas Gascoyne upon the discoverie of the Plot, when I was a Papist.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was the discourse you speak of with Sir Miles Stapleton, do you say?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: It was about the discoverie of the Plot.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: After the money paid?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes, after the money paid: And he said to Sir Miles Stapleton, he had done well to make over his Estate.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That is an abrupt thing for him to say; how did he begin the discourse?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: They were discoursing about the discoverie of the Plot by Dr. Oates and Mr. Bedloe; and then Sir Thomas Gascoyne said to Sir Miles Stapleton, I have done well to make over my Estate to Sir William Ingleby, to prevent a forfeiture.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What said Sir Miles Stapleton?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I do not know what he said, very well.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You seemed but now, as if he had said he was in the Plot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Jones.
sp.p: Did he own he was in the Plot?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: At several times.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serjeant Maynard.
sp.p: Tell the manner how he was concerned.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: My Lord, in the year 1676, I did hear Sir Thomas Gascoyne say to one Christopher Metcalfe, that he was resolved to send 3000 l. to the Jesuits in London for the carrying on of the Designe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What time in 76?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: The beginning of the year 76.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: To whom did he say so?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: To one Christopher Metcalfe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you a Papist then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When came you first to be a Papist?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: About Whitsontide, 75.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Jones.
sp.p: You are a Protestant now?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I am so.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you turn Protestant again?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I turned Protestant upon the discovery of this business.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Either the beginning of May, or the latter end of June.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: To whom did he speak it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: To Christopher Metcalf •… , who then lived in his house.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What said he?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: He said, he was to send 3000 l. to the Jesuits in London, for the carrying on of this Designe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who was in the Room besides?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: None but Sir Thomas Gascoyne and Metcalfe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where is that Metcalfe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: He is since dead I think.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What discourse had they about the Designe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: They were discoursing about it when I came in; and I remember he mentioned 300 l. for Corker, 300 l. for Harcourt, and 300 l. for Cornwallis; and the rest by 300 l. apiece to other Persons.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What name did Cornwallis go by besides?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Pracid, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: That's the name that is to the Letter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Pemberton.
sp.p: Well, what do you know more?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p:
My Lord, Sir Thomas Gascoyne told this Christopher Metcalfe, that he would return it by 300 l. at a time, to prevent suspition, by the hands of Richard Phisicke; and about the beginning of the year 77, I did hear Sir Thomas Gascoyne say, that he had
returned it, and that if it had been a thousand times as much, he would be glad to spend it all in so good a Cause.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he say he had returned all the 3000 l.?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he tell you how it was to be disposed of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: It was to be disposed among the Jesuits for the carrying on of the designe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That was in the general; but this 900 l. you speak of, was to those three Priests.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Jones.
sp.p: You say he resolved to send 3000 l. to the Jesuits at London about this designe; pray what was the designe? what did they say about the Plot at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: My Lord, at other times I have heard them say, it was for killing the King.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What said Metcalfe to all this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: He did allow of it, and thought it was the best way so to do. I have seen him return several sums by Richard Phisicke.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Dolben.
sp.p: Was Metcalfe a Papist?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes, and he died so, as I have heard.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was you in the Room when they first began the discourse?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I came in when they were discoursing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You came in when they were talking, you say; but they did not stop talking because you came in?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: No, my Lord, because I knew of it. I was brought in by one Rushton, who was acquainted with the Plot, to know of it, and therefore they did not stop when I came in.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You say, he said, I will return 3000 l. to the Jesuits in London: did he say in what time he would send that 3000 l.?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: No, but in 76 he said he would do it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And it should be employed for carrying on of the designe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes, those were the words.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
And in 77 you heard him talk with
〈◊〉
again, and then he said, if it had been a thousand times as much, he would have sent it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was no body there but he, Sir Thomas Gascoyne, and you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: No body else.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then go on now with your Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p:
My Lord, in the year 77 several Gentlemen did meet and assemble together at Barnbow-hall in the County o •…
•… ork, Sir Thomas Gascoyne's house; and their resolution was this: That they would build a Nunnery at Dolebank, in case that their designe and Plot of killing the King should take effect, and the Roman
Catholick Religion be established in England; upon which account the Company there present did resolve they would lose their Lives and Estates to further it. And Sir Thomas Gascoyne did conclude he would give 90 l. a year for ever for the maintenance of this Nunnery: upon which, they all agreed, that after his death he should be canonized a Saint.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who were these Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Sir Miles Stapleton, Charles Ingleby, Esquire Gascoyne, my Lady Tempest, Thomas Thwing, Sir Walter Vavasor, Sir Francis Hungatt, and Robert Killinbeck a Jesuit, and William Rushton a Romish Priest.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Pemberton.
sp.p: Is he dead?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: No, he is fled beyond Sea.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who else?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: These are the persons I can remember at present.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: There was a woman there, you say?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: My Lady Tempest, my Lord, and one William Rushton, if you had not him before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Dolben.
sp.p: That was your Confessor?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes, and engaged me in the Plot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Pemberton.
sp.p: What was your discourse? pray tell that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: The discourse was upon establishing a Nunnery at Dolebank, in hopes that the Plot of killing the King would take effect; the intention was to alter the Government, and introduce the Romish Religion.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who was it said this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: It was spoken by Sir Thomas Gascoyne and the rest of the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: In their discourse?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did they speak of killing the King?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, Sir Francis Hungatt said it several times.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How? upon what account?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: They were mutually resolved, and they would talk that they would venture their Lives and Estates in hopes the Plot would take effect; and accordingly about Michaelmas 1677, or near upon as I remember—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long staid they there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: About six or seven hours.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you with them in the Room still?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: My Lord, I was sometimes in the Room, and sometimes out. What discourse I heard, I tell you; there was one Barloe—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What was that Barloe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I have had two Orders of Council for the seizing of him, and never could take him; he is a Priest.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he by?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: He went with them to take possession of the Nunnery.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he not in the house?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: No, not in the Room at that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was there any servant by in the Room, when this discourse was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, go on.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Accordingly Sir Tho. Gascoyne did erect a Nunnery about the year 77, at Dolebank.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What, built it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: He established it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who were the Nuns?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Mrs. Lashalls was Lady Abbess, Mrs. Beckwith and Mrs. Benningfield, were her Assistants, Ellen Thwing, Eliz. Butcher, and others, were Nuns, according as I heard Sir Tho. Gascoyne say: And when they went by Sir Tho. Gascoyne, when one Mary Root was taking horse, Sir Tho. Gascoyne said of her, There goes an old Maid and a young Nun.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Whither were they going then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: To take possession of the Nunnery.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was it a new-built house?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: They called it a Nunnery in hopes their Plot would take effect.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was it an old or new-built house?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Nay, I never saw it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where abouts was this house?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: It was neer Ripley.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What, was that Ripley his house?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: No, his house is at Barmbow.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who did it belong to?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: They went thither till the business was done, and that was onely till the King was killed, and afterwards they resolved to reside at Heworth.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long staid they there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: They lived in this place neer a year and an half.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Till the Plot was discovered?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Jones.
sp.p: How do you know they lived there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I have seen several times Letters come from their hands.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Jones.
sp.p: How do you know they came from thence?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: The Letters were dated from Dolebank.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he let them lie open?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Sometimes he did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What was in them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I don't know any of the Particulars; there was no great matter in them.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: Who writ them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol:
sp.p: The name that I saw was Pracid or from Mrs. Lashals.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: They, or some of them.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: You do not know whose House it was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: No, my Lord, not I.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: Where is Heworth Hall?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Heworth Hall is about half a mile off of York.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Does not that belong to one Mr. Dawson?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: It did, but it was bought of him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: What other place did you hear him mention?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Broughton, my Lord, but I never knew that any were there.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: Nor at Heworth Hall?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, sometimes one and sometimes the other; some of them came to Heworth Hall, and some to Dolebank, but Dolebank was the place they did generally reside at. And then Sir Thomas did establish ninety pounds a year which was purchased of Mr. Timothy Malevorer and Alver Alo •… tus enjoyes it.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: How much was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Ninety pounds a year.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: Where does it •… e?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: It lies at a place called Mawson near Sir Tho. Gascoynes house.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: Did he say he had sealed such a Conveyance?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: I suppose he bought it of Dawson?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: He bought it of Maleverer.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: Is Maleverer a Protestant?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: You did not see the Conveyance of it your self sealed?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: No, I refer to their words for that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: To what purpose was it bought?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: To establish a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: And they told him he should be canonized for a •… aint when he died?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: Well go on then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p:
My Lord, about March last, to the best of my remembrance, Sir Thomas Gascoyne, and Esquire Gascoyne being in their Chamber together, I was reading a Book, called The Lives of the Saints, and Esq Gascoyne told Sir Thomas, that he had been before the Justices of the Peace, and they had given to him and Mr. Middleton license to go up to London, which mentioned, that in consideration that there was a Suit in Law between James Nelthorp Esquire, and Sir Thomas Gascoyne, therefore it permitted the said Thomas Gascoyne Esq and his Man to travel peaceably to London. And I did hear the other Copy read of Mr. Middletons license to travel into the South, and for his occasion into the South parts was pretended to receive some Rents there. But I did hear Esq Gascoyne say to Sir Thomas, that he was resolved as soon as he came to London, and had done with Mr. Nelthorp that he would fly into France & so would cheat the Justices, for he was resolved
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
not to come back to york-shire again, but he would commit the design in agitation into such hands as would do it, and would not fail, but he would not stay to see execution.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: You heard him say so?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: What said Sir Thomas?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: He commended his Sons and Mr. Middleton's Resolutions.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: What Room was it in?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: It was in Sir Thomas own Chamber.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Was there any Rooms near it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: None that they could hear in, unless in the Chamber within, I don't know whether any one was there or no.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Could they hear in no Room that was near to them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes in the Chamber within.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Was there no Servant there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Not as I know.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: My reason is, because he must speak very loud to make his Father hear him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes he did, for I heard him in the Chamber Window that I stood in against them, they were are a little way off me.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Because if any of the Servants were near, methinks they must needs be very Cautious how they spoke so loud to make Sir Thomas Gascoyne hear.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: My Lord, he was not so deaf then as they say he is, and he seems to be now. And Esq Gascoyne also because he would be sure there should no damage come to him caused all his goods to be sold off his ground, and Mr. Middleton sold his very houshold goods.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: He is a Papist too, is he not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes he is so.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Was not he at the meeting with Sir Miles Stapleton?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Middleton was one.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: You did not name him before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pember.
sp.p: But he said a great many were there besides those he named.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dol.
sp.p: Yes he did so. Well go on Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p:
My Lord last 30th of May, the day after Holy Thursday as I remember, being in Sir Thomas Gascoynes own Chamber, Sir Thomas Gascoyne bid me go into the Gallery next to the Priests Lodgings, and after a little time one William Rushton my Confessor, came to me, and asked me if I was at the last Pontefret Sessions. I told him yes, and that I had taken the Oath of Allegiance as others had done, whereupon the said
•… on told me, that I and all the others were damned for so doing if we kept the same. Therefore he bid me be sure to come next Sunday to have absolution from him, for it was a damnable sin to take that Oath, and he told me he had power from the Pope to absolve me, and he added, that few Priests had that Power that he had.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Did he make you confess that as a sin to him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: No, my Lord, for I did make the discovery soon after.

sp.speaker: 〈◊◊〉 Just.
sp.p: When was it you first turned Protestant?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: In June, my Lord, after that.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Then you were not a Protestant at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Where you a Pap •… t when you took the Oath of Allegiance?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I was.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Why would not you then go and be absolved according as your Priest bid you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: I thought I had done nothing that was evil, because several had taken the Oath with me as you shall hear afterward.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Well go on.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: I told him that several others had done, as well as I, that were Papists, and they judged it lawful, whereupon he said, Away, and told me I was a fool, and knew not how to judge of an Oath.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: So you were satisfied the Papists might take the Oath?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: My Lord, I told him I thought it was no sin to take that Oath, because it was an Oath only to be true to my King and to my Country, and I told him that Mr. Ellis Priest to Mr. Vauasor had written comentaries upon the Oath and justified the taking of it. Said he again, Mr. Ellis was a fool and his Superiors will call him to an accompt, and check him for his paines. But said he by taking the Oath you have denyed the power of the Pope to absolve you from it, but I tell you he hath a power to depose the King and had done it: and said he, you will merit heaven if you will kill him.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Who spoke to you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Rushton my Lord said, it was a meritorious Act to kill the King.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: But did Sir Thomas Gascoyne or any of the Company wish you to do that thing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Not at that meeting, but afterwards Sir Thomas did, my Lord, if you will give me leave to go on.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: What did he say?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: He told me he would assist me in the Act.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Rushton did. And he told me the Pope had granted him the power, that I should have the benefit of absolution if I would do it. I desired him not to perswade me to do such a thing, for I would have no hand in it; then he quoted a certain place of Scripture to me which was, thou shalt bind their Kings in Fetters and their Princes in Chaines. Whereupon he concluded, and made this exposition, that the Pope had deposed the King, and absolved all his Subjects, and it was a meritorious Act to kill the King. And that unless the King would turn Roman Catholick the Pope would give away his Kingdomes to another?

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Well go on.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Then I told him I would have no hand in that Act and deed, whereupon he answered me again, you may hang me if you please for speaking these words. No Sir, said I, I will do you no injury if you do your self none. So he •… id me consider what he said, and come to him againe, but I did not.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: This was the 30th of May▪

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, and the same day as soon as I came down. I was told Sir Thomas Gascoyne had left order with his Servants that I should not depart the house till he came in, and I stay'd there till about six of the Clock.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Did not you live with him then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: I lived a little way off the house.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: How far?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: About a Quarter of a mile.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Were you not his Servant?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: No, my Lord, not at that time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jon.
sp.p: How long had you been gone out of his service before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: I went out of his service about the beginning of July 1678.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pember.
sp.p: Did Sir Thomas Gascoyne send you into this Gallery?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pember.
sp.p: And there you found Rushton?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: My Lord, he was not there when I came, but he came as it were from Chappel,

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You were his Servant when all the Gentlemen met at his house?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I was.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: When did you leave his service say you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: The first day of July 1678.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: And this was in May 1678, was it not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: No in (79) my Lord, last May. My Lord I watched and stayd till he came in, and took him as he came in. I went up stayers with him, and when we came into his Chamber he calls me to him, and asked me what discourse had passed between me and Rushton; I told him our discourse was concerning the Oath of Allegiance, and the lawfulness, or unlawfulness of it. Then Sir Thomas Gascoyne took me by the hand, and told me, well man if thou wilt undertake a designe that I and others have to kill the King, I will give thee 1000. l. and I will send thee to my Son Thomas, if he be in Town, but if he be not in Town, he said he would give me such Instructions that I should find the rest that were concerned in the business.—

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: The rest, what?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: The rest that were in the Plot.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: That you should know where to find them in London, you mean so?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, if he were gone beyond Sea.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: What said you to him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: My Lord, I told him I would have no hand in blood, and would not do such a wicked deed, and desired him to perswade me no more. Then he desired me of all love to keep secret what he had said. But afterwards I recollected that it was a very ill thing, and went immediately to the Justices of the Peace.—

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: How soon did you go?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Soon after.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: To whom did you go?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: To Mr. Tindal a Justice of Peace, and to Mr. Normanton.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Did you make an Oath there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, that Sir Thomas promised me 1000. l

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: And for what purpose?

sp.speaker:
Mr.
•… ol.
sp.p: For Killing the King.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Did you put that in the Oath you made?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: What time was this after the discourse?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: It was about a week or such a time.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Was it the next day?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Was it within a fortnight?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, I believe it was my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Was it not a month?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: No it was not above a fortnight, for Sir Thoma •… Gascoyne was apprehended in July or thereabouts I believe my Lord.

sp.speaker: L Chief Just.
sp.p: But was that the first time that Sir Thomas ever spake to you to kill the King the 30th of May?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jon.
sp.p: You say you left Sir Thomas service in July 1678?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, the first day of July.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: How did you leave him in good friendship?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord in very good friendship.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jon.
sp.p: Were you in good Correspondence?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: I always went to his house to hear Mass, and oftentimes was there.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: How came you to leave his service?

sp.speaker: M. Bol.
sp.p: It was my own fault I left it.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Why, it might be no fault neither. But why did you leave it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: My Lord, it was because there was one Henry Addison, and Bennet Johnson did seek to take my work and service out of my hands. Sir Thomas Gascoyne did desire me to let them come in to see what they could do, and that I should have my Sallary, and that I should gather in his Debts; I was willing to be rid of it, and told him they that looked after the Pit should gather in the Debts, for I conceived else it would be but a double Charge to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dol.
sp.p: This is only how he left Sir Thomas his service, Sir Thomas thought the other men could do it better then he, and so said he then let them do your whole work.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just Jon.
sp.p: But he says he did usually resort to the house after he had left his service to hear Mass.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dol.
sp.p: They will ask him some Questions, 't may be.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Had you any Estate of your own when you left Sir Thomas service?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes: I had a Farme I rented of Sir Thomas Gascoyne.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: What Rent?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: 15. l, and a Mark a year, after I was married.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: When were you married?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: In July (75) But afterwards I was there, and did still service.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: I think you have some estate of your own besides that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, I have 7. l. a year.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: Well, will you for Sir Thomas ask him any Questions?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bab.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Mr. Bolron, pray what did the Justice say to you when you made this Oath?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p:
My Lord, thus, I was resolved to come to
〈◊〉 , and make •… Confession here, and desired I might so do, whereupon one of the Justices were unwilling, but at last they said, I might do what I would.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: You say Justice Tindal it was sworn before, what did he say when you made the Oath?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: My Lord, as I remember, he said, he must give the Council an account of it, and perhaps he should not have an answer of it in a moneth after, so I thought it was better to come to London, and make a speedy dispatch of the business, for I did not know but the Priests in the mean time might escape.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But did Mr. Tindal do nothing upon that Oath that was made?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, he did make out his Warrant for the apprehending of one.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he not make out a Warrant for the apprehending of Sir Thomas Gascoyne?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: My Lord, I •… hink they would have done it, but I desired I might come to the Council.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pembert.
sp.p: How long after came you there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: As soon as I could get ready.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What time came you thither?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: My Lord, I sent out upon Monday and came hither to London upon Wednesday▪

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know what moneth it was in?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: In Iune it was, I think.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And who did you come and apply yourself to in London, when you came there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: My Lord, I had a Letter directed from Mr. Justice Tindal to his brother Tindal in London to carry me to the Council. I chanced to lose this Letter at Ware, and losing it there, I came to the green Dragon in Bishopsgate Street, I was acquainted with the Man of the House and having told him some of my business, he carryed me before Sir Robert Ctayton, and than we went to my Lord of Shaftsbury President of the Council, and presently got an Order of the Council about me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long was this after Dr. Oates discovery? when did Oates and Be •… oe make their discovery?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pembert.
sp.p: This was a long time after, in May last.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Did Mr. Tindal take your Examination in Writing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: He took a short thing in Writing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Did you set your hand to it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pembert.
sp.p: He resolved to go to the Council and tell them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: •… was not willing to tell the Justices all, for I had a mind to go to the Council.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: But you told them the great matter of all, Sir Thonas's proffer to give you 1000 l. to kill the King.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Had you a Lease of your Farm under Sir Thomas Gascoyne?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: It was but a Lease parol.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: For how long?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: For nine years.

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: May I have leave to ask him any Questions?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you may.

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbing.
sp.p: You say you had a Leafe of the Farm, a Lease parol.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Yes, I had so.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Mayn.
sp.p: Council must not be allowed in matter of fact my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: But Brother, this man hath made a long Narrative.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Mayn.
sp.p: Ay, and a shrew'd one too.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: His Evidence is very great, and Sir Thomas Gascoyne does not hear any one word.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: One thing more I would speak to. It was in September 1678 a little before the discovery of the Plot, I did hear Sir Thomas Gascoyne say, and tell my •… ady Tempest, that he would send 150 l. to Dolebanke in hopes the blow would be given shortly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ser. Mayn.
sp.p: That is the same word used by all the Wittnesses.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: In September (78) the Plot was not known by us to be discovered then, as I know of.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Who did he speak it to?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: To his Daughter the Lady Tempest.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: What said she?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: She seemed to like it very well, I did not hear any thing to the contrary. And I heard a Letter read afterwards from Cornwallis that he had received it, but it was too little for the carrying on so great a designe.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Who is Cornwallis?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: And it was for the arming the poor Catholicks when the blow should be given.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Is his Daughter living?

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: Yes, she is out under bayle.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recor.
sp.p: My Lord, I shall desire to ask but one Question which concerns the Prisoners at the Bar. How long after the discourse that you had with the Priest in the Gallery was it that Sir Thomas Gascoyne spoke to you of the same thing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pem.
sp.p: Mr Recorder, if you ask him but one Question let it not be that which he hath answered before, he says the same day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hob.
sp.p: I desire to ask him one Question.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pem.
sp.p: No, tell Sir Thomas first what he hath said, and see if he will ask any Questions.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hob.
sp.p: Sir Thomas, here is Mr Bolron hath given Evidence against you, will you ask him any Questions?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pem.
sp.p: Read your Minutes to him.

div.p: Then Mr. Hobart repeated the first part about his coming to Sir Thomas Gascoyne's service and the Colliery Conveyance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jo •… .
sp.p: Ask him if he will ask any Questions upon this part,

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gas.
sp.p: No, tis no great matter at all, for it is true, when twas I can't tell, there was something I did seal to Sir William Ingleby, and some mony I had of him.

div.p: Then Mr. Hobart repeated his saying to Metcalf he wo •… ld send 3000. l. to the Priests in (76)

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gas.
sp.p: How comes that, I deny that utterly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bol.
sp.p: Tis all true that I have said by the Oath that I have taken.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gas.
sp.p: There is no such thing at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hob.
sp.p: He says, it was returned by Mr Phisick.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gas.
sp.p:
Phisick was a Servant to me, and he returned some money •… or me sometimes, but it was all for my Children, my Sons, and my Daughters
and my Kinspeople, to whom I paid Annuities, but 'tis a far greater sum n the whole than 3000l. and for one great sum of 1000l. you know how it was disposed of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hob.
sp.p: He says that in the beginning of 77, you said you had returned this 3000l. to London, and if you had 1000 times as much you would give it for so good a Cause.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gase.
sp.p: I never said any such thing, never thought of any such thing in my Life.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: Now tell him of the meeting at Barmbow.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hob.
sp.p: He says in the year (77) there were seyeral Gentlemen met at your house at Barmbow.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: Name them

sp.speaker: Mr. Hob.
sp.p: These were all together with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gasc.
sp.p: No such matter at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hob.
sp.p: And he says all these persons did discourse with you about the establishing a Nunnery at Dolebanke, and another at Heworth, and another at Braughton.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gas •… .
sp.p: Not one word of all this is true.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: Tell him what he said concerning killing the King.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hob.
sp.p: He says that the Nunnery was established at Dolebanke, and such and such were Nuns.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gasc.
sp.p: He may say what he will, but not one word of all this is true.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolb.
sp.p: But you skip over the main thing what the Gentlemen resolved upon at that meeting.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hob.
sp.p: He says these Gentlemen did resolve the business should go on for the killing of the King, and that they would venture their Lives and Estates for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gasc.
sp.p: I never heard of any such thing as killing the King, Sir, did I ever say any such thing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolr.
sp.p: It was in your own dining Room, and in your own Chamber.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemb.
sp.p: He did not say so, I think, about their meeting.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: Yes, he says, they all met at his house, and there they had discourse of killing the King. In what Room was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolr.
sp.p: In the old Dining Room.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gasc.
sp.p: I deny it utterly. There was no such thing. Some persons might be at several times at my house, but no such meeting, nor words at all at one time or other.

div.p: Then Mr. Hobart told him of Mr. Gascoines and Mr. Middletons Licenses to go to London, and intention to go to France.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gasc.
sp.p: 'Tis very true my Son did go to London for that end.

sp.speaker: M. Hob.
sp.p: And so Mr. Middleton upon pretence of receiving Rent.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gasc.
sp.p: I cannot tell about Mr. Middleton,

sp.speaker: Mr. Hob.
sp.p: He says your Son would immediately fly into France, and commit the design into other hands, and you said you approved of it, and this he heard you discourse very plainly.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gasc.
sp.p: But I plainly deny it all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hob.
sp.p: He says you bid him go up (the 30th. of May) to the Gallery to Mr. Rushton.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, not to him, but when he was in the Gallery Rushton came to him.

div.p: Then Mr. Hobart repeated the Discourse with Rushton about the Oath of Allegiance.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You need not tell him what Rushton said.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, it is convenient.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: For I told him our Discourse about the Oath of Allegiance my self.

div.p: Then Hobart repeated Sir Thomas's further Discourse and Proffer to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: There is nothing of all this true. He might come there and talk with any body, for what I know, but I was not with him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But ask him what he says to this, that he proffered him 1000 l. to kill the King?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: Where should you be paid it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I would not undertake the Design.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: Did you ever know I was Master of 200 l. together in my Life?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Tell him he sayes he would not undertake it, and therefore it was in vain to appoint where.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: I utterly deny it all, upon my Life; that's e'en just like the rest, I never heard it before.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He puts it to you, whether ever you saw him have 200 l. together?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I have seen 500l. at a time in the House, and I have seen in Phiswick's hand 700 l.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: What Phiswick might have of other mens moneys I do not know, he never had so much money of mine.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: My Lord, Sir Tho. Gascoyne I believe had at that time, at least 1200 l. a year of his own Estate.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: I wish he would make it good.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: My Lord, 'tis true enough, I believe he hath setled some Estate upon his Son, about 600 l. a year.

sp.speaker: L. Chief. Just.
sp.p: I can't tell what becomes of the Papists Estates, nor how the Priests drain them, but there are men of very great Estates among them, but they are greatly in Debt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: Will you ask Mr. Bolron any Questions?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: You have not repeated to him one part of the Evidence, that in September (78.) he said to my Lady Tempest he would send 150 l. to Dolebank, in hopes the blow would be given shortly.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: I know no such thing at all. There is not one word of all this true.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: Will you ask him any Questions or no?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: I know not what Questions to ask, but where the money should be paid?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That can be no Question, for the thing was never undertaken.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: Then pray, Mr. Mowbray, tell your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: My Lord, and you Gentlemen of the Jury, I came to Sir Tho. Gascoyne's in the beginning of the year 1674.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you his Servant?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Y •… s, my Lord, but never an hired Servant.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: In what quality did you serve him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: In his Chamber, my Lord, and continued with Sir Thomas until 76, in which time I did observe Mr. Thomas Addison a Priest, Fincham a Priest, Stapleton a Priest, Killingbecks a Priest, and Thwing the elder, and the younger, several times to visit and confer with Mr. William Rushton, Sir Tho. Gascoyne's Confessor.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. J.
sp.p: Were you a Papist then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Are you one now?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, go on then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: I being very diligent in attending Mr. Rushton at the Altar, I became in great favour with him, and was permitted to be in the Chamber when the Priests were in private with him, and I heard them often talk and Discourse of a Design laid for setting the Popish Religion uppermost in England, and how like the same was to take effect in a short time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who did speak it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: The Priests in private with Mr. Rushton. I speak now, my Lord, of the Plot in general, I come to Sir Thomas Gascoyne anon.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When? in what year was this Discourse?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, what said they?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Why, they discoursed concerning the setting up the Popish Religion in England, and how like the same was to take effect, and succeed, in regard that most of the considerable Papists in England had engaged to act for it, and if it could not be done by fair means, force must be used; and particularly declared, that London and York were to be fired.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What? would they fire it again?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: And I heard them often say, that the King in Exile had promised them—

sp.speaker: L. J. C.
sp.p: Did they say the City was to be fired the second time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes, to further their intention.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: It was effected in Southwark.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: And they did also declare, That the King when he was in his Exile had promised the Jesuits beyond Sea to establish their Religion, whenever he was restored, which they now despaired of, and therefore he was adjudged an Heretick, and was to be killed.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who did say this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: The Priests.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who was the Heretick?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: The King. Also I did hear Mr. William Rushton tell Addison and the rest of the Priests—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know which of the Priests said the King was to be killed?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: It was Rushton. Rushton and Addison were together, and he did declare to Mr. Addison, that according to Agreement he had given the Oath of Secresie and the Sacrament to Sir Thomas Gascoyne, Esquire Gascoyne, his Son, my Lady Tempest, his Daughter, and Mr. Stephen Tempest, and had communicated the whole Design to them.

sp.speaker: L. J. C.
sp.p: Were you by, when he said this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes, in his Chamber.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long after the Discourse of the Priests was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: My Lord, he told them he had done it according to Agreement before; and they did approve of it, and had severally engaged to be Active, Faithful, and Secret, and would do to the utmost of their powers, as far as their Estates would permit, to establish the Roman Catholick Religion in England. And about Michaelmas 1676. there was another meeting of these Priests, and others; where they declared, That the King was an Heretick, and that the Pope had Excommunicated him, and all other Hereticks in England, Scotland, and Ireland, and that Force was to be made Use of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: When was that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: About Michaelmas 1676.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: You were his Servant then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord. And then did Rushton produce a List of Names, of about four or five hundred, and he read them over, all of whom, he said, were engaged in the Design, and he did read the Names of Sir Tho. Gascoyne, Tho. Gascoyne Esq my Lady Tempest, Mr. Vavasor, Sir Francis Hungast, Sir John Savile, the two Townleys, Mr. Sherborne, and others.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Did you see this List?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: I saw several Subscriptions to it, and amongst the rest I saw Sir Tho. Gascoyne's own hand.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes, very well.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And upon the Oath you have taken, do you believe that was his hand to the List?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I do believe it was his hand.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: Did you know any other hands? Don't you know his Son's hand?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: No, nor any but Sir Tho. Gascoyne's.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It was in several hands, was it not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes, it seemed to me to be so.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What did they subscribe to do?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: This was in 77?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: No, it was about Michaelmas 1676.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What was it for?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: The Title of it was, as I remember, A List of them that are engaged in the Design of Killing the King, and promoting the Catholick Religion.

sp.speaker: L. C. Just.
sp.p: Was that writ on the Top?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: They were words, I suppose, to that effect.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes, it was to that effect, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was it mentioned in the List, for Killing the King?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes. And then they declared also, That the Pope had given Commission to put on the Design, and prosecute it as quick as they could, and that he had given a Plenary Indulgence of 10000 years for all those that should Act either in Person or Estate for killing the King, and setting up the Romish Religion in England, besides a Pardon and other Gratifications. And so much As to the Plot in general. Now, my Lord, I come to the particulars as to the Prisoner at the Bar, Sir Tho. Gascoyne. About Michaelmas 1676. much about that time, there was Sir Tho. Gascoyne and his Son, my Lady Tempest, and Rushton the Priest together, where I heard them hold several Discourses of this Design about killing the King, and firing the Cities of London and York; and Sir Tho. Gascoyne did declare and assure Mr. Rushton, that he would not swerve from what he had said, but would keep to the Oath of Secrecy he had given him, and that he would do to the uttermost of his Power for the killing the King, and the Establishment of Popery.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you in the Room?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: I stood close at the door, where I heard very well, the door was not quite shut.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: They did not know you were there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: They would not trust you with it then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: They did not know I was there. And they did unanimously conclude, that it was a meritorious Undertaking, and for the good of the Church, and they would all venture their Lives and Estates in it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Rushton was there, was he not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes, Rushton was there: and Dr. Stapleton, a Priest, coming from another Door, and finding me at the door, went in and desired them to speak lower, for there was one at the door. Whereupon my Lady Tempest called me in, and ordered me to go below and entertain some strangers. So much for the particulars concerning Sir Tho. Gascoyne.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Was Sir Miles Stapleton there at that time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes, he was there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: In an Upper Room.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who were by?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Mr. Gascoyne, and the Priest, and my Lady Tempest.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: This is all you say.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes, so far as to the particulars of this matter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: Have you any more to say?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: No, no more but these particulars, unless some Questions be asked.

div.p: Then Hobart began to repeat this Evidence to Sir Tho. Gascoyne, how he came to be his Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: He came as a Boy to me, without hiring.

div.p: Then Mr. Hobart repeated the Priests Discourse at Rushton's.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: I deny it all.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He was not present, this was a Discourse among themselves.

div.p: Then Hobart told him about the Oath of Secresie and the Sacrament.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: No, there is no such thing, there is not a word of it true.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then tell him of the List.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: 'Tis a most impudent Lye.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: What say you to your Hand being to that List?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: Not one word of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: But he sayes 'twas your Name to it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: He had a pair of Spectacles on sure that could see any thing. Was it a printed List, or a written one?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: It was written, your Name was put to it, with your own hand-writing.

sp.speaker: Sir. Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: He makes what he will.

div.p: Then Mr. Hobart repeated Rushton's declaring that he had given him the Sacrament of Secresie.

sp.speaker: Sir. Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: I'll warrant you he hath gotten this Oath of Secresie out of the News Books, for I never heard of it before. Let me ask thee? Didst thou ever hear it before you came to London?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes, Sir Thomas, I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: But will you ask him any Question?

sp.speaker: Sir. Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: No; it is all false he speaks, not a word of Truth comes out of his Mouth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: My Lord, We will now go on to another piece of our Evidence.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: I must leave it to the Jury to take notice of their Conversations and mine.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: Whereas he says he was never owner of 200 l. together, we will produce his own Almanack under his own hand.

sp.speaker: L. J. C.
sp.p: Do it, and we will shew it him, and see what he sayes to it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: Why did not he discover it before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: If your Lordship please, Sir Thomas desires he may be asked why he did not discover it before?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Because the Papists did threaten me at such a rate, and I, being a single Person against them, durst not.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you first discover it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: It was about Michaelmas last. The Papists did threaten me, that if I did discover it they would take my Life away.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Just.
sp.p: When did you turn Protestant?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: When the Plot broke out, then I took the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why did you not discover it as soon as you turned Protestant?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: My Lord, I was not in a condition to make any Friends, or come up to London upon such an account; besides, my Lord, they did threaten me; and particularly after the Plot was come out, Addison did threaten me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But this was a great while before the Plot broke out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: So long he continued a Papist, and then he would not discover.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: This Addison was often with me, and he flatter'd me, and made me continue a Papist, least I should discover it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where is he now?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: He is fled.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What said Addison when you did turn Protestant?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: He said if I did discover, he would take away my Life.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I wonder they did not give you the Oath of Secresy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes my Lord, I did receive it from Rushton's own hand.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: In 76.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
