sp.p: Who receiv'd it with you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: It was given to me after the Communicants were gone from the Chappel.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What was the Oath?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: He reserved the Sacrament for me, and swore me by it, that I should be faithful and secret, and should not reveal any Discourse I was privy to.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Reveal no Discourse, what Discourse did they mean?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Those Discourses when the Priests were in private with him.

div.p: Then Sir Tho. Gascoyne's Almanack was produced.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: Who proves Sir Thomas his hand? Is this Sir Thomas Gascoyne's hand?

sp.speaker: Bolron and Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes, it is his Hand.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Shew it him himself,

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: Is that your hand?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: Yes, I think I saw it at the Council Table, this is my Writing, and I will justifie every word that is written there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Read that one place.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: The 15th to Peter for a 100. l. to Corker.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: If your Lordship please, I desire he may be asked what that 100 l. was for.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: Look you here Sir, did you order 100 l. to be paid to Corker?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: It may be I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: What was it for?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: For the Portion of a Child I had.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: What Child was that?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: I know not who it was, Mary Appleby, I think.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Pray ask him how it came to Corkers hands? Why it was returned to Corker.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: I know not that, because wee did not know where she liv'd, she was beyond Sea.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: Where is she?

sp.speaker: Sir Tom. Gascoyne.
sp.p: She is at Paris.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Here is another Book of his that does make mention of 900 l. to Mr. Corker upon Agreement between them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ask him how much money he might return to Corker from time to time.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: My Lord I don't know, we have been several years returning of money.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Hath he return'd 800 or 900 l. in all?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: No, I don't think so much.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: Pray ask him how much was Mrs. Appleby's Portion.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: Indeed I can't certainly say, but as the Rents came in, I was to pay several Sums to several Persons, it was a 100 l. a year to that Mary Appleby, it may be 2000 l. in all from first to last, but I shall satisfie you about that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Will you satisfie us anon why 900 l. was paid in one year.

div.p: Then the Book was shewn to Sir Thomas, who owned it to be his hand.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Read it.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Q. of Mr. Corker, what Bills, for how much, and to whom directed, he hath received of me since the 21th of July 1677. to June 1678. vid. the Book, p. 45. and the great Book, fol. 54. where you may find P. for 900. l. and agree in this Accompt Corker, the 7th of August, 1678.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: First he makes a Quaere, how much he returned, and then says he, the 7th of August I and Corker agreed.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Let him read it himself.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: What say you to that, that you sent so much Money to Corker?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: You must understand he is one of the Priests, and Bolron swears, that he intended to send 2000. l. and by 300 l. a piece, he reckons up 900. l.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: It was a great many years, and several times.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Tell him it was but between July 77. and June 78.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: That does not appear.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Yes, it does, by the Book.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Then how came you to return 900. l. in one year to Corker?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: And never had 200 l. he says together.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: Then here is another Passage in this Book, if it please your Lordship to have it read.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Take Heworth at an easie Rent of the Widow—and purchase the Reversion of Craddock—and in the Interim Dawson.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Ask him what he did mean by taking of Heworth?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: I took no House there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: But did he agree to buy the Reversion of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: It was for my Neece Thwing. She was born in the house, and was very desirous to be in the House.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Ay! but why did he take the Lease of the Widow, during her Joynture, and why buy the Reversion?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: I know no Reason but my Affection to her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Ask him who he did intend should live in the House?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: Nay, I don't know what they intended my Neece Thwing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Did you intend to buy it for yourself?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: No, I lent her the Money.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Did you intend it for her?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: I might do with it what I would.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p:
Ask him if his Neece Thwing was a single Woman, and was
to have the whole House to her felf?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: She had her Brother with her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: He sayes Mrs Ellen Thwing was a Nun, Mrs. Lassels was to be Lady Abbess, Mrs. Beckwith was her Assistant, and Mrs. Cornwallis and others were Nuns.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ask him if Mrs. Lassels was not to be Lady Abbess and live there?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: I know nothing of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Ask him if there was not one Mrs. Benningfield to be there?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Yes, she was to be there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Why, do you know any thing of her?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: She is in York Gaol.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: No, she is gone from thence. My Lord, Ellen Thwing was a Nun, and was sent for from beyond Sea to instruct all them that should be made Nuns, and this Father Cornwallis was Father Confessor to the Nuns. He is now in York Goal, taken with two Women.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Ask him what he meant by that writing in the Almanack?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: I did write things here for a Memorandum to help and assist my Neece, and the poor Children of my Brother; and so the Widow that was Sir Walter Vavasor's Sister, was to sell the House, and one Craddock meant to sell all the Lordship, and the Children were desirous to keep the House, and so they bought the House and one Close, and all the rest was sold; so I writ it onely that they should have the assistance of Sir Walter Vavasor to have the House.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Pray ask him what he means by the words, in the interim at Dawson.

sp.speaker: Sir. Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: Nay, what do I know.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ask, if Mrs. Thwing were not a Nun?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: They did desire if they could not get that House, that they might have another House.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: And all this for Mrs. Thwing. Ask him if she was not beyond Sea, and kept in a Nunnery?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: Nay, I can't tell what she was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Here is another Note in this Almanack, pray read it.

div.p: It was sirst shewed to Sir Tho. Gascoyne, who owned it to be his hand.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Mr. Harcourt, next House to the Arch within Lincolns-Inn-Fields, Mr. Parr's.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No question but he was acquainted with all the Priests about the Town, and had directions to write to them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: He hath been Priest-ridden by them, that is plain.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Ask him what he means by the last Mark there set under London?

sp.speaker: Sir. Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: I can't tell what it is, 'tis a Quaere.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p:
In the Almanack there is a Memorandum to acquaint Mr.
〈◊〉
with the whole Design, what it was, I can't tell.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, Pray let's see that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: This Thwing is a Priest, in Newgate at this time.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: The 15th of April 1676. Memorand. Acquaint Mr. Thomas Thwing with the whole Design.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Now shew him that.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gasc.
sp.p: Look you, what is it you would have?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: What Design was that?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: It was my providing moneys for him and his Sister, that they should tell how to purchase the House.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What, a Priest and a Nun?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolb.
sp.p: They had vow'd contrary to that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemb.
sp.p: Ask him whether Thwing be not a Priest?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: Is this Thwing a Priest? Thomas Thwing?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: No, it was Ferdinando Thwing, that is now dead.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: No, but this is Thomas Thwing: Is he a Priest?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gasc.
sp.p: I do not know, what have I to do?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then consider how likely it was, he was to purchase an House for a Priest and a Nun, for some such business as is sworn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: He sayes no, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is the meaning of it then, that he should name the whole Design?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: He sayes it was the Brothers and Sisters that lived next door to him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, but 'tis said, Acquaint Thomas Thwing with the whole Design.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: He might acquaint Thomas Thwing with such his intention.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We will now shew your Lordship a Letter, taken among the Papers of Sir Thomas Gascoyne, wherein is this Proviso, talking of the Settlement, In the formal Settlement, let this Proviso be added, If England were converted, then to be disposed so and so.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Bolron, how came you by that Paper?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I took this Paper in Sir Thomas Gascoyne's Chamber, with several others, I remember some had his hand to them, others had not, and some were signed Pracid, and some Cornwallis.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Is there any mark of his Hand to that Paper?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Yes there is a mark in this, of Sir Thomas's own hand, the word (Yes) in the Margent.

body.p:
AFter most grateful Acknowledgments of all your charitable Favours, as to my own particular; I am also herewith to present most humble and heartiest thanks on behalf of your Neece, and Mrs. Hastings here, who both would esteem it a great happiness to see you here, as also my Lady, your honoured Daughter, to whom we beseech our humble Respects may be presented. I have sent the Paper safely to good Mrs. Bedingfield, from whom shortly you will have Religious acknowledgments. I told her, that I suppos'd you would judge fitting to insert into the formal Writing the Proviso, viz. That if England be converted, then the whole 90 l. per annum is to be applyed here in Yorkshire, about, or at Heworth, &c. the
which, doubtless, will be as acceptable unto her, and as much to 〈◊〉 as possibly can be imagined. Now, dearest Sir, let me not be too much troublesom, save only to wish you from his Divine Majesty, for whose everlasting Glories greater Praise and Honour you do this most pious Action, the happy Enjoyment of that Glory everlasting. I would lastly advise you in Gods holy name, to compleat the Business by drawing the formal writing as soon as possible; & withoutYES. making any material Alteration from what you have already signed, save only the Proviso above written. I should be glad to know concerning the Receipt hereof; and when Sir Miles and your Son are likely to attend you to finish the Business: as also when Mr. Pierpoint shall be arrived. These good Religious are very desirous with your Approbation (and Mrs. Bed. at my coming from her wished the same) to try for a Removal to Mr. Dawson's; th'impediments here being essential, as the house incapable to receive more Scholars, with many other Inconveniences also. Time permits no more, only we again express our earnest desires to see your Honour here with my Lady, as the greatest Satisfaction we can desire: I remember you hinted to Mrs. Beding. not long since, that perhaps you might see her at Hammersmith. and how much easier you may come hither, we earnestly beseech you to take into Consideration to the Purpose.

closer.signed: Your Honour's most obliged faithful Servant, JO. PRACID.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I think 'tis pretty plain, there was a Design of erecting a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: If England is converted then the whole 90 l. a year to be employed in Yorkshire about a rotten House, which would be much for Gods Glory.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What other Evidence have you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: If your Lordship please, we have another Letter Dated from York Castle, and the backside of the Letter is indorsed by Sir Tho. Gascoyne's own hand, the time when he received it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: The last May, he dates it from York Castle, where he was in Prison, and therein gives Sir Thomas an Account of the Opinion of the Doctors of Sorbonne about the taking the Oath of Allegiance.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No Doubt all of them do not approve of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: As I believe this same Pracid was the Occasion of so many Gentlemen refusing the Oath of Allegiance, I convicted above 40 of them in that County for not taking of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: Noscitur ex comite. You see if this be the effect of it, what reason we have to rid our selves of these Priests. One that dares write such a Letter, and 'tis found in Sir Thomas's Study.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: And Sir Thomas's own hand on the back of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p:
My Lord, under Favour, I do take it, that the debauching of men in point of Conscience, that they may not take the Oath of Allegiance is to set them loose from the Government, and loose from the King,
and make them ready to arm when they have Opportunity.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: No Doubt of it Brother.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: All the Jesuits say they may not take it, but some of the Sorbonists say they may.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: But now you see they are against it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Some will, and some will not allow it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: They take or leave Oaths as it is convenient for them.
Then the Letter being shewn to Mr. Mowbray, and the Indorsment acknowledged to be Sir Thomas's hand was read.

body.p: LOnger time having pass'd since your last writing, it is fit to inform you how Gods holy Providence disposes concerning us. All the Out-prisoners being call'd into the Castle, (as you may have heard) Mrs. Hastings Room was needed, and so she went into Castle-gate to reside at the former lodging of one Mrs. Wait, (who is now in the Jayl) where she remains with Mrs. Wait's two children, and their Maid-servant, teaching the children, as formerly; also the Moor's Neece goes daily thither; and Mrs. Hastings lives without charge as to Diet and Lodging, as I formerly told you; she spends all her time well, God be praised, and comes every morning about seven a clock to serve God at the Castle: but I and two others are much abridg'd of that happiness by her Room being left by her here. My liberty of going abroad is restrain'd with the rest, none being as yet permitted the least, since these last were forced to come in. Madam was here the other day, and seem'd somewhat timorous about Mrs. Hastings teaching: but most in the Castle perswaded her, that it was most commendable and most secure, and so she rests satisfied: Mrs. Cornwallis is recovered of her Ague, God be blest: she desires her dutiful respects may be alwayes presented unto you, and intends her self to write to you. Mrs. Wood and her Companion are well, but dare not as yet walk in their own Garden. All our now Prisoners are chearful, and each of us comforted, in hopes that God will make all Catholicks of one mind: for I have a Letter from our Mr. Record. That is Superior. Spr. at London (who was the same day taken and carried to Prison) wherein he declares, alledging Authority, That the pretended Oath of Allegiance cannot be taken, as it is worded, adding, that three Brieves have formerly been sent from the Pope, expresly prohibiting it; and in the third, it is declared damnable to take it. And yesterday we had a Letter communicated amongst us, sent by Mr. Middleton (now at Paris) to his Friends here, containing the attestation of all the Sorbon Doctors against it; adding, that whosoever here in England give leave, they deceive People, and are contrary to the whole •… atholick Church. There was also a meeting some years ago, of all the Superiours both Secular and Regular, wherein it was unanimously declared, that it could not be taken. Mr. Hutchison (aliàs Berry) who has lately printed a Pamphlet in defence of the Oaths, has the other day declared himself Protestant at St. Margarets Westminster. And so I rest,

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: That is all, the other is private.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: If your Lordship please, we shall now prove by some Witnesses, That he hath returned great Sums of Money, because he said, he never had 200 l. together; and for this we call Mr. Phiswick;
Come Sir, were you a Servant to Sir Tho. Gascoyne?

sp.speaker: Mr. Phiswick.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: For how long time?

sp.speaker: Mr. Phiswick.
sp.p: For six years and upwards.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: In that six years time what Sums of money did you return to London?

sp.speaker: Mr. Phiswick.
sp.p: 'Tis abstracted in a Note.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you return all the Sums in that Note?

sp.speaker: Mr. Phiswick.
sp.p: I refer my self to my Almanack.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you set down this Account?

sp.speaker: Mr. Phiswick.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then thus, Sir, pray what comes it to?

sp.speaker: Mr. Phiswick.
sp.p: Those Sums do come to 6128 l.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Whose money was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Phiswick.
sp.p: Part of it was Sir Thomas's, part his So •… s, and part my Lady Tempest's.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Can you tell how much in any one year you returned upon the account of Sir Thomas?

sp.speaker: Mr. Phiswick.
sp.p: Not unless I had my Almanack.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It will be endless to look over the particulars.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Can you make any Estimate 〈◊〉 six years how much you returned for Sir Thomas himself?

sp.speaker: Mr. Phiswick.
sp.p: No, not without my Almanack, because I returned money for them all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lady Tempest and Mr. Gascoyne, it hath been proved, were in all the Discourses.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But that hath not any influence upon Sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phiswick.
sp.p: The Esquire lived much in London.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolb.
sp.p: What Estate had he to live upon?

sp.speaker: Mr. Phiswick.
sp.p: Betwixt 4 and 500 l. a year.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemb.
sp.p: What Estate had Sir Thomas besides?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: My Lord, I believe it was 1600 l. a year, besides what Mr. Gascoyne had.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolb.
sp.p: And what had my Lady Tempest?

sp.speaker: Mr. Phiswick.
sp.p: Three hundred pound a year.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: But she lived in Yorkshire?

sp.speaker: Mr. Phiswick.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: So she needed little returns to London?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: But admit they had returned all, yet there was 300 l. a year to be returned for Sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, here is Mr. Mawson, I think 2500 l. was received by him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Phiswick.
sp.p: I paid in the Countrey, at Leeds, money, that he paid here in Town.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Here is 25 l. paid to Harcourt, I would ask him whether it were the same Harcourt that was executed?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: I think that not material.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, if you please we will shew you the Examination taken before the Council, that Sir Thomas did own this Bolron had bin his Servant, and never unfaithful, but always took him to be, as he now found him, a Fool.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: If he object any thing, it will come in properly by way of reply.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then now we have done till we hear what the Prisoner says to it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Tell him they have done with their Evidence against him, if he will have any Witnesses examined, he must call them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobert.
sp.p: The Kings Evidence have bin all heard, and said as much as they can, the Court askes you if you would call any Witnesses, or say any thing for your self? have you any Witnesses here?

sp.speaker: Sir Thomas Gascoyne.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: Name them, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Ask what he will have done with them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Let him tell us to what purpose he will call them.

sp.speaker: Sir Thomas Gascoyne.
sp.p: To Examine them to the credit, and demeanour of these Men, and that there is no probability in their suggestions.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: Name them, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: They are all in that Note.

div.p: Mr. Babbington was first Examined.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Ask Sir Thomas what he would have him asked.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoin.
sp.p: Look you, Sir, what do you know concerning the difference between Mr. Bolron and I?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, what say you to that Q •… estion?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: My Lord, I have not been imploied in Sir Thomas Gascoin's business before the last Winter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolbin.
sp.p: What do you know then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: About Spring last Sir Thomas Gascoine was consulting with me about Money Bolron owed him upon two Bonds, and gave me Directions to sue them. And likewise he was giving me Directions to deliver Declarations in Ejectment for gaining the possession of his Farm, because he did not pay his Rent—.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How much were the Bonds for?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: I have them here I think.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You need not look for them, you may tell us the Sums.

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: The one is for Twenty eight pounds, the other Twenty, to the best of my remembrance. Mr. Bolron having notice of this, did desire he would accept of a Conveyance of an House he had at Newcastle for satisfaction of his Debt. Sir Thomas was unwilling to accept of it, but I did prevail with him to accept it, not in Satisfaction, but as an additional Security; and the Deeds I have here that I drew for that end.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: What time was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: This was a little before last Trinity Term begun. I have taken a Memorandum within a day or two, if your Lordship will give me leave to look upon it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Have you not had all this time to get your Papers ready?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: My Memory is very short indeed. But now I see about the third or fourth of June Sir Thomas gave me orders to deliver Declarations in Ejectment.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: When did he first bid you question him for Monies upon the Bonds?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: It was sometime in May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he tell you, you must sue him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What t •… en did Bolron say?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: Bolron did then desire that Sir Thomas would accept of Security out of his House at Newcastle. Sir Thomas was very hard to be perswaded, but at length I did prevail with him, and I used this Argument, That it was not to lend so much Money upon that Security, but his Money was already out of his hands, a •… d else desperate, and this was a further security, and that it would not lessen his other Security, and upon these perswasions he did let me draw a Deed to that purpose.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was this some t •… me in May?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: This d •… course was in May.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Are you sure of it?

sp.speaker: Mr. 〈◊〉 .
sp.p:
The directions that I had for drawing the Deed was in June, but the discourse with Sir Thomas was in May, and I do per •… ectly remember it by a Circumstance which I shall tell your Lordship. A •… er the Deeds were drawn, (for drawing of which I had a Letter under B •… lrons own hand, and if occasion be I have the Letter here to produce) I came from York, having bin there, and appointed a day for the Sealing of them. I came to the House where Bolron lived, and Sir Thomas met me, and there •… produced the Deeds, and he of himself was very ready and willing to •… he sealing of them, but his Wife, who was joyned in the Deeds wi •…
•… im, would not by any means seal, unless Sir Thomas would deliver up the Bonds he had taken for the Money, but Sir Thomas did utterly refuse to deliver up the Bonds.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What time in June was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: A little before Whitsontide.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What time was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p:
That was the 14th of June, as I remember, that I delivered the Declaration; and that day before, which was the 13th to the best of my remembrance, I had this Communication and discourse about Sealing the Writings, which the Wife refused to joyn in; but Sir Thomas would only take it as an additional Security, refusing to deliver up the Bonds, but he would suspend further prosecution, and Bolron did then desire no longer time then a month for payment of the Money. But his Wife tho she were urged to seal the Writings would not be perswaded, but utterly denied it. After we had spent a great deal of time there, Bolron comes to me and desires me to come another time, and he would perswade his Wife to seal the Deed; nay, said I, 'tis not fit for me to come up and down unless it be to some purpose, and your Wife will Seal; Will! nay, saies he, I will force her to it. My answer was this, if you take these Courses, Mr. Bolron, I must by no means be concerned in the matter; for your Wi •… e must pass a Fine, and we must examine her •… ecretly, and if she tells me she does it by your
Force, I will not pass it if you would give me a 1000 l. After this about a fortnight he sent for me to come and his Wife would Seal.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: By the way, are you a Protestant?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: Yes, I am Sir.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And always was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Yes, he is an Attorney at large, I know him very well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: This was a fortnight or three weeks after that, the latter end of June, he sent for me to his House, and that his Wife would be contented to seal. And this he desired might be done on the Tuesday, which was Leeds Market-day, and I could not go. The next day I called upon him at Shippon-Hall; he was then within, a •… d desired me to go up to Barmbow to Sir Tho. Gascoyn's with him: he said he should go within two or three days to Newcastle, for he had a Chapman that would lay down the Money, and take the security of the House, and he desired he might have the liberty to go thither to treat about it. I told him I did believe it would be no hard matter to perswade Sir Thomas to that, for he would be very glad of it. I went up with him to Barmbow, and as we went along, he asked me if Sir Thomas did intend to sue him upon his Bond? I told him I had directions so to do. He asked me likewise if he would turn him out of his Farm? I told him, Yes, if he would not pay his Rent; and the truth of it is, he did then deny he had received the Declaration in Ejectment: but my Man afterwards made his Affidavit of delivery, and had Judgment upon it. Afterwards I went up to Sir Thomas, and told him what Bolron desired, and he consented to it as readily as it could be asked; and in coming away he told Bolron, that in the management of his Coalpits he did neglect very much, and did go abroad, staying away two or three days together. To this Bolron made some excuse, and said it was for collecting his Debts. Said Sir Thomas, I know not what you are about, but if you do well for your self, I am satisfied.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long had he been from him, and left his Service then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: I know not when he went, but this was in June last. After this we went back again, and in coming back he was very inquisitive to the same purpose; he was asking me—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You say he child him, and told him he was not a good husband in his Coalery.

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: Yes; and as we came back he was inquisitive whether Sir Tho. Gascoin would sue him, and turn him out of his Farm. I did then enter into the same expressions, and told him, if he did not pay, he must be sued.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You told me, Sir Thomas was agreed to stay so long, when was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: My Lord, this was after we had parted with Sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: After Sir Thomas had prom •… ed him to s •… ay so long time, then said he, as you were coming home, Do you think he will sue me, and turn me out of my Farm?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbing.
sp.p: Yes, said I. Well, said he, Then by God I will do that which I did not intend to do. What he meant by it. I cannot tell, but this was a little before he came to London, which I judge to be the latter end of June; and this is all I have to say.

div.p: Then Obadiah Moor was called.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Did you tell Sir Thomas Gascoyne, what he said, Then I will do what I never did intend to do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: I did never tell him my Lord, for I look'd upon it as an idle expression. And I will tell your Lordship why; because this Man that is now to be examined did tell me how that he was bound for him, and that Bolron to incourage him to be bound, said, You need not fear, for if Sir Thomas sues me, I will inform against him for keeping Priests in his House; and I did look upon it as an idle expression.

sp.speaker: Mr. Moor.
sp.p: My Lord, in September last was 12 Month, Mr. Bolron did desire me to be bound with him to Sir Tho. Gascoyn. Said I, I told him, Mr. Bolron, I have some small Acquaintance with you, but I have no reason to be bound with you. Said he, Do not fear; there is my Brother Baker, and Stephen Thompson are to be bound as well as you. Said he, I will give you my Counter-security. That signifies nothing, said I. You need not fear any Suits, said he; for if Sir Thomas sues me, I will inform against him for keeping Priests. Said he, When must this Money be paid? Said he, at Candlemas next. So we went and were bound; the one Bond was to be paid at Candlemas last, and the other in August. And after Candlemas he did not pay the Money, and said I, Mr. Bolron, I don't like these Bonds, you must make new Bonds for my security. I was afraid of being sued, and I desired Mr. Babbington to bring a Writ against him, which he did; and upon Holy-Thursday I had two Bayliffs ready to arrest him, but he could not be found; and I had two likewise the Saturday before at his Pi •… s. Presently after he came up to London, and made an Information, and on the 8th of August last I met him in Ferry Bridg, and he came along with me; said he, Mr. Moor, you and I have often discoursed of Sir Tho. Gascoyn, you may do me good, if you do not, pray do me no harm. You have been often at his House. With that, I asked him if he was concerned in the Plot? for, said I, you have been often telling me, and sworn it, and deny'd it utterly, that he was no more concerned than any body else: but I did but equivocate then, for I was a Papist, and if I had told a 1000 Lies, or killed 20 Protestants, our Priest would have forgiven me for it. And so coming to Farnborn, two Miles from Ferry-Bridge, he plucked out 10 s. and said, I have no more Mony in my Pocket but this, but pray be kind and do me no harm, for you know I have deni'd it all along.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Hath he done so?

sp.speaker: Mr. Moor.
sp.p: Yes, several times.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How came you to disourse with him, and question him about it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Moor.
sp.p: Because there was a general Discourse in the Contrey, that there were few Papists but what were concerned, and guilty of the Plot.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was that Discourse?

sp.speaker: Mr. Moor.
sp.p: The latter end of September was 12 Month, when the Plot ws first discovered. And he said, Sir Thomas was no more concerned than the Child that was to be born.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Had you any Discourse with him about May last?

sp.speaker: Mr. Moor.
sp.p: No, my Lord, in August as I told you I had.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was the last time that he told you, Sir Thomas had not an hand in the Plot?

sp.speaker: Mr. Moor.
sp.p: I can't certainly remember, but I think it was in February, when I told him I would sue the Bond, or have better security. It was a small time after Candlemas.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: What are you, a Protestant, or a Papist?

sp.speaker: Mr. Moor.
sp.p: A Protestant, bred and born so.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: He would have sworn it no doubt at that time, for he was under an Oath of Secrecy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you say August was the first time that he discoursed to you that Sir Thomas was in the Plot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Moor.
sp.p: Yes.

div.p: Then Stephen Thompson was called.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Well, what do you know of this Business?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompson.
sp.p: My Lord, if you will give me leave to speak, I know a great deal of the Unkindness betwixt Sir Thomas and Mr. Bolron. He came down to me, he was Sir Tho. Gascoyne's Steward of his Coleary, and Sir Thomas liked not of his Accompts, and turned him forth. There was a great deal of Mony owing to Sir Thomas, and he came to Sir Thomas to agree about it, and he desired me to be bound with him to Sir Thomas: Said I, Mr. Bolron, how shall I be secured? Said he, there is a great deal of Money of which I never gave Sir Thomas any accompt, I will gather it in and secure all, and so Sir Tho. Gascoyne knew nothing of it. So Bonds for 60 l. were entred into to pay 28 l. at Candlemas. So Sir, when Candlemas came, and he did not pay the Money, I went up to him, and asked him what he would do about this Money, what course he would take to satisfy? Oh! never fear, said he; why said I, hath he any hand in the Plot? if he hath let us know it; for he had made a great deal of his Goods away, and then I thought I should not be secured, Oh said he, he is a sin less of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who did make away his Goods?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomson.
sp.p: Bolron did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomson.
sp.p: Candlemas last. For then I thought Sir Thomas might sue me for the Money, and I would feign have known if Sir Thomas had any hand in the Plot, and I pressed him much to tell me. Then it passed on, and having a Writ out against me, I durst not stir out my self, but I did send my Man to him to know what he did intend to do about it. He told my Man, Brother, tell thy Master he need not to fear at all; why said my Man, do you know he hath any hand in the Plot?—

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: That is but what your Man said.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Is your Man here?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompson.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Therefore you must not urge that he said to you, 'tis no Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thomson.
sp.p:
On Thursday after I went up to him my self, and got him to go up to Sir Thomas, and so when he came to Sir Thomas, he would give him no time but a fortnight to pay the Money. Bolron desired but three weeks time, and he would procure him his Money. So away we came down. Said I, What do you intend to do in this case? Said he, If he do sue me, I will do •… im an ill •… urn; and soon after he went to London, and said, he would go to sell his Land at Newcastle. And a while after I went out to see if he were come again, and meeting him, it was when he was going
to London again to •… arry on his designe, said I, Robert Bolron what do you say in this Case, you are going now to leave the Country, and how shall I be secured against Sir Thomas? do not question it, said he, for I am to receive on the Kings Account 30 l.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Upon whose Account?

sp.speaker: Mr. Tompson.
sp.p: Upon the King's, concerning the taking Sir Tho. Ga •… .

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: But I never had a farthing of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompson.
sp.p: But said he, I will not take it, for another bids me threescore pounds, and I know what Oats and Bedloe had, and I won't aba •… a farthing of that.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Thompson.
sp.p: It was after he had taken him; and on Holy Thnrsday he did say, If he did sue him, he would do him an ill turn.

div.p:
Then the Lord Chief Justice being to sit 〈◊〉
Nisi prius at GuildHall, went off.
William Backhouse was next called.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Let him ask Backhouse what he will.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyn.
sp.p: I would ask him what Threats he gave to his Wife to swear against her Conscience, and pro •… ise of 500l. he should gain by it.

sp.speaker: Backhouse.
sp.p: I served the Warrant to carry the Witnesses before Esq Lowther, and Esq Tindall. I was charged the 7th of July last to help fetch the Witnesses before the Justices, and to take Sir Tho. Gascoyn, I and two of my Sons; and he opened the Door his own self. When we had taken him, Esq Lowther directed us to bring the Witnesses before him, and we did so. When we came to Bolron's House, his Wife was sick on Bed, and I said that she must go before the Justice of Peace to swear against Sir Tho. Gascoyn for High Treason. She said she knew nothing against Sir Thomas. But Bolron said she must go, or he would have her drawn at the Carts Arse.

div.p: Then Hamsworth was called.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: What will he ask him?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyn.
sp.p: I ask him about the Threatning of his Wife.

sp.speaker: Hamsworth.
sp.p: May it please you, my Lord: The same day that Sir Tho. Gascoyn was taken, Robert Bolron came to his Wife and told her, she must go to Esq Lowther to swear against Sir Tho. Gascoin. She fell a weeping, and would not go by no means: he threatned if she would not go, he would tie her to the Horse's tayl.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Did he tell her what she should swear?

sp.speaker: Hamsworth.
sp.p: I did not hear him, only to swear against Sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: What she k •… ew, was it?

sp.speaker: Hamsworth.
sp.p: Yes; and she said, she did not know any thing of Misdemea •… our of Sir Thomas Gascoyn touching his Sacred Majesty, or the Church. Government.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Art thou sure he said those words?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: My Lord, he is a Papist.

sp.speaker: Hamsworth.
sp.p: I am a Protestant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: How long have you been a Protestant?

sp.speaker: Hamsworth.
sp.p: I was born so.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Well, thou hast added a few fine words that I dare say she never said.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Were you never a Papist?

sp.speaker: Hamsworth.
sp.p: Yes, I was.

div.p: Nicholas Shippon was called.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: This Man is a Papist too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Do you think he is not a Witness for all that?

sp.speaker: Sir T. Gascoyn.
sp.p: What discourse he had May 30, the day after the Race.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Well, ask him what you will, what do you say

sp.speaker: Shippon.
sp.p: Mr. Bolron was with me the 30th day of May.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: What, May last?

sp.speaker: Shippon.
sp.p: Yes, the day after Ascension-day: He came to my House about two a Clock in the afternoon, and staid at my House all that afternoon while an hour after Sun set before he went away. He came and brought a Letter with him to carry to Newcastle, and it was sent away thither.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Are you sure it was the day after Assension-day? How if it should fall out to be another day?

sp.speaker: Shippon.
sp.p: Yes, Assension-day was the 29th of May. He came to me about two a Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: Pray what reason had you to take notice of this?

sp.speaker: Shippon.
sp.p: He came and brought a Letter to me that was to goto Newcastle, and desired me, that my little Boy might carry it to a kinsmans▪ house of mine, for he said, he was afraid of the Bailiff, and did not care for stirring out. My Wife brought him some meat and drink, and he said it was better than he had at home; and she said she was the more sorry things were no better with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: But how came you to take notice that this fell out the 30th of May?

sp.speaker: Shippon.
sp.p: The night before I met him coming from the Race, which was the 29th of May, and he asked me if I saw any Bayliffs waiting for him? and I said, Yes. And he said it was well if he missed them. And he asked me if I saw Bennet Johnson?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: How long was it you say he staid?

sp.speaker: Shippon.
sp.p: He came about two a clock▪ and staid till an hour and half after Sun-set.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: What Religion are you of, Friend, let us know?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: What say you to the truth of this, Bolron?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: My Lord, there is not a word of it true: for I was about two a clock at Sir Thomas Gascoyns. They were marking some Sheep, and I was there most of the Afternoon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Were you ever at his House at any other time to send any such Letter?

sp.speaker: Mr. Balron.
sp.p: I never sent any such Letter. Indeed that day I was a little of the afternoon at his House, but I staid there but half an hour; but I was most part of the afternoon at Sir Tho. Gascoin's seeing them mark Sheep.

div.p: Then Roger Gregson was called.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: What do you say to him?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoin▪
sp.p: Let him speak his knowledge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: I desire he may ask the Question▪ for he only generally refers to them what they know.

sp.speaker: Sir Thomas Gascoyne.
sp.p: What did he say to you about August last?

sp.speaker: Gregson.
sp.p: My Lord I will tell you, we met about August last, Robert Bolron and I, about a week before Bartholomew day. We had some discourse, he came from London a little before that, and I asked him how Sir Thomas Gascoyn did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Was he apprehended in August last?

sp.speaker: Gregson.
sp.p: Yes, he was in the Tower. He said, Well. I asked him, how he would come off about the Plot (as they call it)? Said he, he may come off well enough, but it will cost him a great deal of Money. I then did ask, how they came to fall out? And he said it was long of that Rogue Addison, Brother to the Priest, who had called him to accompt, or else he had never done Sir Thomas that injury. And I suppose that was the cause of it. And then we had some more discourse, and that Discourse was this, he rides a little from me (he was on Horse-back) and came back again, said he, I can tell you, the King was at Windsor, and one of the Privy Council made an attempt to stab the King, and the King made his escape, and now they will believe my Informations the better.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: Gregson.
sp.p: That is all I have to say.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: What, are you a Papist?

sp.speaker: Gregson.
sp.p: No, I am no Papist, I deny it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: Nor never was?

sp.speaker: Gregson.
sp.p: Nor never was.

div.p: Then J •… mes Barlowe was called.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: My Lord, I conceive this Man ought not to be heard, for he is under an Accusation of the same Crime; and we have had two Orders of Council to apprehend him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: There was an Order of Council within this fortnight, to send for him up in Custody.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: There is nothing upon Record against him, and you may discredit his Testimony, but you cannot refuse him: He is not to come upon his Oath.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Bolron swears too that he was at the Consultation.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Let us hear him what he says, we must leave it to the Jury what to believe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: They would question him about Mr. Bolron's cozening, which ought not be.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: This man hath sworn it against him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: Why did you not indict him, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: Sir, you ought not to prate here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Come, I doubt you are a little too pragmatical.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: If you had any Record of the Indictment to shew against him, we would not examine him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: Will you ask him any Questions, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: You know, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: That is not proper, he tells him what he knows.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Look you, Sir, we did not intend that you should come here to manage all as a Counsel; it was said, he could not hear well, and so you were only to tell him what was said.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyn.
sp.p: I would ask him what he does know concerning taking of Money, and stealing from me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: But that must not be asked.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyn.
sp.p: Then you must tell me what I must ask.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Come, you have been pragmatical, Sir, and made him a Brief, and he cannot manage it without you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: Did you write this Brief?
sp.stage: (meaning a Brief in Sir Tho▪ Gascoyns hand.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: No, and't please you, Sir.

div.p: Then Mr. Ravenscroft offered to speak what this Witness had told him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Look you, Mr. Ravenscroft, if what he says tend any thing to this business, that Sir Tho. Gascoyn comes to know of his stealing, and then turn'd him out of his service, it is material; but if you come to tell a story here of another man's knowledge, we can't spend our time so.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: It was known but last night to me; and if you will not let me tell you what it is, how should you know it?

sp.speaker: Mris Ravenscroft.
sp.p: He is a Chief Witness for my Grandfather, and I desire he may be heard, for he discovered it but last night to my Husband.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: If it tend any thing to this business, that Sir Thomas turn'd him out of Doors, and therefore this Man bears him an ill will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: We had as good hear Mr. Ravenscroft however; but pray, Sir, make your story short.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: He came to me and said these words, I have kept a Secret a long while, in which I have done very ill,—

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Then it does not tend at all to this Affair; for you must not come to tell a story out of anothers man's mouth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Pray sit still, Sir, and be quiet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Indeed you must be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: If you have any other Witnesses, call them, and do not spend our time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: For the Jury must be told that 'tis no Evidence coming out of another Man's mouth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: 'Tis as if a Man should come and say, I can say something for Sir Thomas Gascoyn, when I know nothing but what another Man told me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Ask Sir Thomas if he would have this Barlow examined?

sp.speaker: Sir Thomas Gascoyne.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Then what Questions will you ask him?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyn.
sp.p: What Conspiracy was had to take away a great deal of Money from me, and how he conceal'd it because he would not do him a Mischief.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: What is that to Sir Thomas's Life?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: I cannot tell you by bare Assertion, but if you will hear what I have to say, do. Last night, late at night, about nine a Clock, Barlow came to me, says he, Mr. Ravenscroft—

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Come, don't tell us the Preamble, but the Story.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: Said he, I have a thing that sticks upon my thoughts, which I doubt may endanger Sir Thomas's Life.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Well, was it about taking Money?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: Said he, If I am silent▪ I doubt it will cost Sir Thomas his Life. Then I asked him what it was? Says he, Mr. Mowbray, who is a Witness in this Court, and I, did, just a little before his going away, combine, or rather he did •… educe me—

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Was it about Money?

sp.speaker: Mr Ravenscroft.
sp.p: Money is in the Case.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: He did conspire, what to do?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: If you will hear me, I will tell you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Pray do it quickly then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: Did combine to wrong Sir Thomas of a great Sum of Money; and whereas I held my tongue, thinking not to spill his Blood, I see now if I do not tell the truth, I shall make good his Credit, and so endanger Sir Thomas's Life.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Well, I'le ask you, or any man alive now; Two Men combine to rob Sir Thomas whether one Man be a competent Witness against the Credit of the other Witness? He makes himself a Rogue by Combining, and you have made him a Knave by his own Confession.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: I may perhaps err in that word; he did not say, combine, but the other seduced him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: You have told a Story to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: You think it a fine thing to be a Catholick, and to appear brisk for them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: Who says I am a Catholick?

div.p: Then George Dixon appeared.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyn.
sp.p: What do you know of any Conspiracy of these People against me?

sp.speaker: Dixon:
sp.p: My Lord, I was at William Batley's in August last in the morning at ten a Clock, and Mr. Bolron and Mr. Mowbray came in, and called for a Flaggon of Drink, and when it was brought, they fell into a Discourse together concerning Sir Thomas Gascoyn and my Lady Tempest. Says Mr. Mowbray, I know nothing of Sir Thomas but that he is a very honest man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: He was not bound to tell you what he knew.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: When was this, in August last?

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: Yes; but, said he, if I knew any thing against my Lady Tempest I would discover it, for I would hang her if I could. And they sat •… down at Mr. Batley's House to consult what they should do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just, Pemberton.
sp.p: Before you?

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: Yes, I heard every word.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: And what did they say?

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: They said they would meet at Mr. Bolron's House, and if they could compleat their business they should be very well gratified.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Against whom?

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: Against my Lady, and Sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: But you say, Mowbray said he knew nothing against Sir Thomas Gascoyne?

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: No; he said, he knew no hurt by them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: How come they to say they would contrive their Business?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: What man is that, Mr. Bolron?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I know him not, nor ever held any such Discourse.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: How far do you live off one from another?

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: I live at Leeds, Mr. Mowbray knows me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: I don't know that ever I saw you.

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: He hath drunk with me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: I know him not, nor where he dwells.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just Dolben.
sp.p: What Trade are you of?

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: A Cloth-dresser by trade, but I keep a publick house.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: This Discourse was at Leeds, was it not?

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: They say both, they do not know you, nay they sware it. And 'tis very like you were but very little acquainted, would they let you hear them talk thus?

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: We were as well acquainted as can be, but that he will deny it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray what Religion are you of?

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: A Protestant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How long have you been so?

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: All the days of my life.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I can't but wonder at the strangeness of your Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: My Lord, I have not drunk at that place which is near the old Church at Leeds, not this two years.

div.p: Then William Batley was called.

sp.speaker: Batley.
sp.p: And if it like your Honour, these two Gent. Mr. Bolron and Mr. Mowbray, came to my house, and called for a pot of drink.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you not know this man neither?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes, I do, but I was never three times in his Company in my life.

sp.speaker: Batley.
sp.p: I filled them a Flaggon of Ale, and when I had done I left them. They began to discourse of the Plot, and Sir Tho. Gascoyne; and Mr. Bolron.—

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: At your house, where is your house?

sp.speaker: Batley.
sp.p: My house is near the old Church at Leeds.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Is that the same place the other man speaks of?

sp.speaker: Batley.
sp.p: Yes. Says Mr. Bolron to him, Thou knowest that Sir Tho. Gascoyne hath been very severe against thee and me, and now here is an opportunity offered us to take a Revenge upon Sir Tho. Gascoyne: Mowbray replyed again, As for Sir Thomas, he is a very honest man, and I know no hurt by him; but as to my Lady Tempest, if I knew any thing against her I would hang her, for I would discover it. But thou knowest, says Bolron, that Sir Thomas sues and troubles me, and if I do not make somewhat out against him, he will ruine me, and it must be done by two Witnesses. To which Mr. Mowbray answered again, How shall we bring this business about? If thou wilt but come to my house, said he, I will put thee in a way to contrive it, and we shall have a considerable Reward. And Mowbray told him he would come to him such a day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Was that man that went out last, with you all the time they spake?

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: He does not say half so much as you do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Were you in the Room?

sp.speaker: Batley.
sp.p: No, I was at the Stairs head.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: What did you stand there for?

sp.speaker: Batley.
sp.p: I hearing them discoursing of Sir Tho. Gascoyne, hearked what they did say.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: The other Man said he was in the Room with them; were you in the Room?

sp.speaker: Batley.
sp.p: I stood upon the Stairs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Were you in their Company at all that day?

sp.speaker: Batley.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I carried up a Flagon of Ale.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Was the door left open?

sp.speaker: Batley.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Would any Men talk in such a place as this, that all the World may hear them, when they are contriving to take away a Man's Life?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: You were in the same Room, Dixon, were you not?

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: They were at the Grice head, and we at the foot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: But the other says, he was at the top of the Stairs, the head of the Stairs.

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: We were at the Stairs foot, and they were in the Room.

sp.speaker: Batley.
sp.p: The Table they sate at, joined just upon the head of the Stairs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Did you hear them down to the Stairs foot?

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: We did stand there to hear them discourse.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Could you see them where you were?

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: Yes, as fair as I see you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Could they see you?

sp.speaker: Batley.
sp.p: No, they could not.

sp.speaker: Dixon.
sp.p: Yes, if they had looked down.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Why then I ask you, Do you think, if you stood in so open a place to be seen, and they had seen you, can you imagine that they would talk so about taking away Sir Thomas Gascoine's life?

sp.speaker: Batley.
sp.p: I do imagine they did not know I was there, nor believe any one heard or saw.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Do you know how they came there?

sp.speaker: Batley.
sp.p: They said they came out of Leeds, and said, one Mr. Legat was to come that way, who they were to speak with.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: I ask you, if you were in the Room under them?

sp.speaker: Batley.
sp.p: And if it like your Lordship, I stood at the Stair's foot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Just now you said it was the Stairs head.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Did you say any thing to them about this?

sp.speaker: Batley.
sp.p: No, I did not open my Lips to them about it, but I told it to a Friend about three or four weeks after.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Batley.
sp.p: To a Neighbour of mine: I suppose it was told Mr. Babbington.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: What say you, Mr. Babbington? how came you to know of this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: When the Commissioners of Oyer and Terminer were sitting at Leeds, there was one came and told me, George Dixon could afford me something that would be very advantageous for the benefit of Sir Thomas Gascoyn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Who was that Man?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: Bennet Johnson, or Francis Johnson.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Was that the Man you spoke to?

sp.speaker: Batley.
sp.p: No, I spoke it to a Smith, one Richard Loftus.

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: I'le tell you another Person I heard it from, that was Mr. Bayliff of Leeds.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Well, was this the common discourse of Leeds?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: He says so. Was it then presently?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: The Bayliff did not tell me so suddenly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Would it not have been to your purpose to have brought the Bayliff here?

sp.speaker: Mr. Babbington.
sp.p: It was after the Commission of Oyer and Terminer that I had it from him, which was in October.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: In the time of August I was not at Leeds, I was in Northumberland searching for Priests, and in the Bishoprick of Durham, all but a little of the first of it.

div.p: Then Mrs. Jefferson was called.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: What do you ask her?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: Pray be pleased to speak to the Conspiracy and Combination against me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Whose Combination? Come, Mistris, what do you know?

sp.speaker: Jefferson.
sp.p: I asked Mr. Mowbray one time, what he knew concerning Sir Thomas Gascoyne? And he said, he knew nothing, but Sir Thomas was a very honest Gentleman for what he knew, and the best Friend he had.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Is that all you know?

sp.speaker: Jefferson.
sp.p: He thought he was wrongfully accused.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: When was this? was this after the time he was accused by Bolron?

sp.speaker: Jefferson.
sp.p: It may be it might be, I think it was in August.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: In August las •… ?

sp.speaker: Jefferson.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: But you must needs know (it was the talk of the Country) when Sir Thomas Gascoyne was sent for up to Town; was it after that time?

sp.speaker: Jefferson.
sp.p: Yes, I think it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p:
Then you say, you heard Mowbray say that Sir
〈◊〉 . Gascoyne was an honest Gentleman, and he could say nothing against him.

sp.speaker: Jefferson.
sp.p: Yes, ask him else.

div.p: Then Matthias Higgringil was called.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Was he one at the Meeting?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: He was at the sealing the collusive Conveyance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: This Higgringil is a Protestant, is he not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: I know not, I think so.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Come, Sir, what say you in this matter?

sp.speaker: Higgringil.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: What can you say to the Business about Sir Tho Gascoyne?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyn.
sp.p: Speak to the threatnings to take away my life.

sp.speaker: Higgringil.
sp.p:
I have nothing to say to Bolron; but Mowbray on 25 Septemb. last, being at an Alehouse, Mr. Legat and he were together, consulting how to disgrace Sir Thomas, and take away his Life; and he calls me out
to speak with me: Now, said he, I shall match them, for they have done what they could to disgrace me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: How did he mean that?

sp.speaker: Higgringil.
sp.p: I suppose he had taken away some Money and Gold, and they spoke of it, and that was to disgrace him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Was it charged upon him?

sp.speaker: Higgringil.
sp.p: It was suspected always he had taken it away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: But was there any such thing talked of in the Country?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: What did he say to you?

sp.speaker: Higgringil.
sp.p: He said, they did what they could to disgrace him, and take away his life, and he would requite them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Who they?

sp.speaker: Higgringil.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Gascoyne, and my Lady Tempest.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p:
Why? did Sir Thomas
•… dict him?

sp.speaker: Higgringil.
sp.p: No; but the noise was about the Country.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: When was this? in September last?

sp.speaker: Higgringil.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: What Profession are you of, Higgringil?

sp.speaker: Higgringil.
sp.p: An Husbandman, I graze, and I farm a Farm.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: You know this man, do you not, Mr. Mowbray?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mowbray.
sp.p: Yes; Sir Thomas employs him, he is a kind of Collector to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenscroft.
sp.p: He is no Papist.

div.p: Then Francis Johnson appeared.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Well, come, what do you know?

sp.speaker: Johnson.
sp.p: He hath sustained great Losses by him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: He! who?

sp.speaker: Johnson.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Gascoyne.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: By whom?

sp.speaker: Johnson.
sp.p: By Mr. Bolron.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: What Loss hath he received?

sp.speaker: Johnson.
sp.p: The very first Month he entred, he wronged him of three pound.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: How do you know that?

sp.speaker: Johnson.
sp.p: I cast up the Accompt my self.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: But he kept him two years after that?

sp.speaker: Johnson.
sp.p: Yes, he did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Is this all you have to say?

sp.speaker: Johnson.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: My Lord, I lost three Pounds the first three weeks, and Sir Thomas forgave me it; I don't deny it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Do you know of any malice between them, and that he said he would do him any mischief?

sp.speaker: Johnson.
sp.p: No.

div.p: Then Mr. Pebles Clerk of the Peace in the County of York was called.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyn.
sp.p: I would desire you to speak of the Carriage of Mr. Bolron to you, Sir, what you know.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pebles.
sp.p:
My Lord, I was in York last Assizes, and Mr. Bolron came to me into a Room, where I was with some Gentlemen, and asked me how I did? and asked me if I did not know him? I told him I did not remember him; said he, I am the the prosecutor against Sir Tho. Gascoyne. So when he was sat down, after a little while, he desired to discourse with me, and asked me if a man was indicted as a Traytor whether it were fit to pay him Money? I owe, said he, Sir Tho. Gascoyne Money, and I would know whether it be fit to pay it to him? said I, I think you may safely pay him his Money before he be convicted, but then 'tis the King's in my opinion. Nay, said Bol. he is sure to be convicted. Thensaid I, I think it not safe to pay it therefore I leave that to your own Discretion whether you will or no. Alittle after he desired to have my Opinion concerning the two Judges that came our Circuit, for I am might •… ly abused by them, said he, they will not at all give me Audience; I came from the King and Council, and they slight me, will not hear me speak. Said I, I believe if you will go to them, they will hear you. I went to speak with them, and they sent some of their Servants out to know what I would say to them; but I have wr •… a Letter to them, to tell them my mind, but said I, I can't believe, that any one will presume to carry such a Letter, but for that I will leave it to you. So I came away from him, and after he follows me out, and desires to speak with me again; said he, I have something against you concerning this business in hand, I can do you a prejudice if I will. Said I, God bless me, I know nothing of it, I do not at all intend to court your Favour, I have no mind at all to that. Said he, I will not do it; and he spoke as if he had no desire to do it; I would not court him, but came away and left him; he followed me to the Street again, and said, Will you help to apprehend a Traytor? who is it? said I: It is a Gentlewoman, said he, a Woman greatly concerned in the Plot, you may apprehend her in the Street, and 'tis the best time. Now the Street was full, and I thought it a little unseasonable: so he looked after me, but I never offered to go from him; but said I, was she in the Plot? yes, said he, she was to be the first Lady Mayoress o •…
York after the Plot took effect, and the King was killed; but he did not lay hold upon her. So I parted with her, then said he, I can have no respect; said I, I have nothing to do with you, I am Clerk of the Peace of the West Riding in this County, and am always ready to do my Duty there. So away I went and left him. The next news I heard, was, he had procured a Warrant of the Council against me, and he brings the Warrant to a Justice of Peace, and that Justice of Peace told him there would be several Justices of Peace at Leeds within two or three days after, and then they would examine the Business; I chanced to be in a Room with some Gentlemen, not knowing of the Warrant that was out against me, and this Gentleman that was the Justice of Peace called me into another Room, and told me of this business: admired at it, and told him I did know nothing of it, nor that I had disobliged him, unless it was because I did not give him the Complement
and Ceremony of my Hat, nor give him Money, neither did I know what Information he had procured that Warrant upon. He told me Mr. Mowbray and Mr. Bolron were in Town. So I desired him to send for the other Justices into the Room, where he acquainted them with the matter, and said he, if you will, we will examine it to night; so they sent notice to Mr. Mowbray and Mr. Bolron, that they would examine the Business that night at 6 a clock, and they came, and he was asked what he had to say against me? He said, I had taken Money for keeping a Man from taking the Oath of Allegience, and they had Witnesses to prove it.—

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Maynard.
sp.p: Must he be here admitted to make his own defence?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Brother, let him go on.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pebles.
sp.p: The Witness was call'd upon, and they asked him to that point, and he denyed absolutely upon his Oath that he gave me any Money, and also swore he had taken the Oath when it was tendred to him. Then, my Lord, there was one Mr. Dunford an Attorney, was spoken of as if he could prove something, but he was 14 Miles off, and they could not send for him, and so I begg'd they would appoint another time for hearing when he could be there: they appointed Munday following, and ordered me to attend, and one of the Justices of the Peace undertook to give Dunford notice. Accordingly I came there, but there was no Mr. Bolron, nor Mr. Mowbray, but I desired that Mr. Dunford might be examined upon his Oath, and they did take his Information in writing, and he swore he knew nothing of it, neither did he ever give me Money upon any such accompt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: You were not by when it was sworn?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pebles.
sp.p: I saw the Examination taken in Writing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: And you were discharged?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pebles.
sp.p: Yes, for he could not make out any thing at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: It was well for you he could not make it out.

sp.speaker: M. Pebles.
sp.p: They said they could prove it, and vouched these two persons, but both denied it upon their Oaths.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Is that all you know?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pebles.
sp.p: That is all I can say in particular; I have not a mind to speak against him in general, because he is the King's Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: You can say nothing of his Repute?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: You were a stranger to him, you did not know him.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Gascoyn.
sp.p: I desire he may speak what Reputation he hath among the Justices.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pebles.
sp.p: I have no mind to reflect on the King's Evidence, and if I did, it would seem as if I should speak in malice: he hath done me wrong but I never did him any.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: But what is his Reputation generally?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pebles.
sp.p: Truly 'tis not very good in the Country.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Among whom?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pebles.
sp.p: The Grand Jury and the Gentlemen of the Country.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: Is it a Common Fame in the Country?

sp.speaker: Mr. Pebles.
sp.p: Most people discourse ill of him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Did he say he did not speak with the Judges?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: No my Lord I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: You did speak with us, indeed you would have had us allowed you a Guard for your safety, which we could not do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bolron.
sp.p: Whereas he says I gave in a wrong Information, this same Hunt when he came before them confessed he gave him 40 s. but he would not swear for what it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serg. Maynard.
sp.p: 'Tis nothing to the purpose one thing or other that he hath said.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: 'Tis altogether uncertain; no body knows what to make of it.

div.p: Then Hardwicke was called.

sp.speaker: Sr. Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: Do you speak what Threats Bolron hath used to his Wife to swear against me.

sp.speaker: Hardwicke.
sp.p: When the Pursivants came up to Barmbow, the Chief Constable ordered me to assist Mr. Bolron in Execution of the Warrant, and to carry the Witnesses before a Justice. We went to Robert Bolron's house to take the Witnesses, and there was his Wife, his Brother, and his Sister. We were to carry them before a Justice and they refused to go, his Wife pretended to be Sick and could not go, and they begg'd of us to excuse them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Who do you call they?

sp.speaker: Hardwicke.
sp.p: His Wife, his Brother and his Sister: Bolron told them they must go, and William Backhouse and I ordered them by all means to go along with us, I suppose it was to Testifie what he had sworn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: What were they to do, did he tell them?

sp.speaker: Hardwicke.
sp.p: They were to go to tell what his Testimony was above, as well as I understood the discourse.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: We have had two persons to this purpose before. They say he would have his Wife go, and she refused to go, and cryed; but they do neither of them say he pressed her to speak anything more than she knew or against her knowledge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: No, one of the Witnesses said, he told her it was to •… peak her knowledge.

div.p: Then William Clow was Examined.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Come what say you?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: The 22th. of May last I had a Writ against Bolron, and my man Arrested him and brought him to my house.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: At whose suit?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
At the suit of one Hickringil that was servant to Sir Thoma •… , and there I had him two days and would not carry him to the Gaol, for he begged of me I would not; but then I told him I would keep him no longer there, for he had no money for Lodging and Dyet; but he begged so hard of me, that I would but tarry till Hickringill came, and then he did not care what they did with him: for he would make Sir
Thomas pay Hickringill his Debt that he owed him, or he would play him such a trick as he little dream'd of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: The 21th. or 22th. of May last or thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: May last?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Yes. And so Hickringill came over, and they did agree, and he gave him a Lease of an house he lived in, and Hickringill took the Charge of both the Debts upon him.

div.p: Then Hobart stood up.

sp.speaker: Sr. Tho. Gascoyne.
sp.p: Speak whether he pretended he writ a Letter to the Duke of Monmoth from Leeds.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: My Lord I have nothing to say to that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: What can you say then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: All I can say is to the summes of money returned to Town.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: He did not mention that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: If you please to let me declare what I know about the returning of the money.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Pray speak what you know of your own knowledge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: For most of it I know of the payment of it, and to whom, 1800 l. there was paid to Mr. Trumbal about the purchase, it was paid at Mr. Mawson's; I was a Witness to the Deed, and to the Receipt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: That is some, but what to the rest?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: 200 l. was payed to a Client of mine, 80 l. was paid to one widow Cawson that was upon Bond.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: How much was paid to Mr. Corker?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: Several sums, above 300 l. paid to Corker in 6 years time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Nay in 4 years time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: This 300 l. and 300 l. before I drew the Receipt for, and commonly he Ordered me when Mr. Corker came for it, that I should have a Receipt from Mrs. Mary Appleby, and it came back signed by her, to whom Sir Thomas was Guardian.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: And was all this money paid to Corker upon the account of this Appleby?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: It was mentioned in the Receipt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: How much was she to have by the year?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: 100 l. by the year or two sometimes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: How came she to have 900 l. in 4 years?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: My Lord, I will tell you, for that there was a great Arrear upon a suit between Sir Thomas and Mr. Appleby, this Mrs. Applebys Father; and upon the hearing of the Cause my Lord Keeper Bridgman was pleased to order that this money should be paid to S •… . Thomas for the use of the Daughters, 200 l. a year, that is 100 l. a piece. And there was an Arrear for 3 or 4 years during the Suit, about 2 or 300 l. it was: I drew Receipt for it, and Sir Thomas being pressed for the money by Mrs. Appleby who went beyond sea, he sent to Corker to get the money returned to her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Ay but you Dance about the Bush, was there an Arrear of 500 l.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: For 3 or 4 years, and Mrs. Ravenscroft was one of the Sisters, her part was paid when she was married, but this Gentlewomans was paid beyond sea.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Was the Arrears from Sir Thomas to the Gentlewoman beyond sea?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Are you sure there was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: Yes, Sir Thomas told me so.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Pemberton.
sp.p: Who was to pay this mony?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: Mr. Appleby by order of my Lord Keeper.

sp.speaker: Mr. Justice Jones.
sp.p: Sir Thomas was Guardian, was the Estate in Yorkshire?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: It did arise out of Rents there.

div.p: Then one Culliford was called.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: What say you? What do you know of this matter?

sp.speaker: Culliford.
sp.p: This Gentleman Lodged at such a time at my house, the 4th. of June 1677. he was at my house seven weeks, and he was gone 3 weeks, and returned again; he was 3 weeks away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: What Gentleman was this?

sp.speaker: Culliford.
sp.p: Mr. Mowbray.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: What is that to the purpose?

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Jones.
sp.p: How do you apply that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: Mr. Mowbray hath said he sent a Letter to the Duke of Monmouth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: There hath been no mention made of any such thing. Have you any more Witnesses▪

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Just. Dolben.
sp.p: Then ask Sir Thomas what he hath to say for himself.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hobart.
